metadata.title: Pulmonary Embolism
teachingPoints: Recognize risk factors for VTE: recent surgery, immobility, long-haul travel.
Interpret classic EKG findings for PE (S1Q3T3, RBBB) and signs of right heart strain.
Bedside echo can rapidly identify right ventricular strain (McConnell's sign) in unstable patients.
Massive PE is defined by hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg) and requires immediate intervention.
Thrombolysis (tPA) is indicated for massive PE without absolute contraindications.
Judicious use of IV fluids is crucial to avoid worsening right heart failure.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Acute onset pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath.
initialPresentation.summary: A 62-year-old female with a history of recent major surgery and long-haul travel presents with sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, tachycardia, and borderline hypotension, concerning for a massive pulmonary embolism.

history.presentIllness: Patient reports the sudden onset of sharp, right-sided chest pain approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. The pain is severe, rated 8/10, and is significantly worse with deep inspiration. She also feels profoundly short of breath and describes a sense of 'impending doom.' She denies cough, fever, or hemoptysis. She returned from a 14-hour flight from Australia two days ago.

pastMedicalHistory.surgicalHistory: Right total knee arthroplasty 6 weeks ago
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Smoked 1 pack per day for 20 years, quit 10 years ago. Occasional alcohol use.

initial.description: Patient is anxious, tachypneic, and in visible distress. She is pale and diaphoretic.

physicalExamFindings.General: Alert and oriented but anxious, in moderate respiratory distress.
physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic with a regular rhythm, S1/S2 present. Jugular venous distention noted to the angle of the jaw.
physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Tachypneic with shallow breaths.
physicalExamFindings.Extremities: Warm and well-perfused. No peripheral edema or calf tenderness noted.

stabilizing.trigger: Apply High-Flow Nasal Cannula
stabilizing.description: With supplemental oxygen, the patient's oxygen saturation improves, but she remains tachycardic, tachypneic, and hypotensive. Her anxiety is slightly reduced.

improving.description: Following the initiation of thrombolytic therapy, the patient's hemodynamics begin to improve significantly. Her heart rate and respiratory rate decrease, and her blood pressure normalizes. She reports a decrease in her chest pain and shortness of breath.

orderableItems.result: Sinus tachycardia at 128 bpm. S1Q3T3 pattern present. New right bundle branch block. No ischemic ST changes.
Severely dilated right ventricle with hypokinesis of the RV free wall (McConnell's sign). Flattened interventricular septum.
Large, saddle pulmonary embolus extending into the right and left main pulmonary arteries. Evidence of right heart strain with flattening of the interventricular septum.
Elevated at 0.45 ng/mL. Reflects right heart strain.
Thrombolytic therapy initiated after confirming diagnosis and ruling out contraindications. Hemodynamics begin to improve within 30 minutes.
Cardiology consulted. Agrees with diagnosis and management plan including thrombolysis. Recommends admission to Cardiac ICU.

metadata.title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
teachingPoints: DKA is a triad of hyperglycemia, ketonemia, and metabolic acidosis.
Insulin non-compliance and infection are the most common triggers.
Kussmaul respirations are a compensatory mechanism for severe metabolic acidosis.
Initial management focuses on aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, followed by insulin therapy.
Monitor potassium closely; insulin drives potassium into cells, potentially causing life-threatening hypokalemia.
The anion gap must be monitored and closed before transitioning off the insulin drip.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Nausea, vomiting, and fruity-smelling breath.
initialPresentation.summary: A 19-year-old male with Type 1 Diabetes presents with nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status due to insulin non-compliance, found to be in severe DKA.

history.presentIllness: Patient is a 19-year-old male with a history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) brought in by his roommate for evaluation of 2 days of worsening nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain. The patient has had poor oral intake. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic and confused. The roommate notes he has been breathing rapidly and his breath has a 'sweet, like nail polish remover' odor. His insulin pump reportedly malfunctioned 3 days ago.

pastMedicalHistory.medications: Insulin Glargine and Insulin Lispro via insulin pump (currently malfunctioning)
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: College student, lives in a dorm. Reports occasional alcohol use.

initial.description: Patient is lying on the gurney, appears ill and lethargic. He is breathing deeply and rapidly (Kussmaul respirations). He is slow to respond to questions.

physicalExamFindings.General: Lethargic, ill-appearing young male in moderate distress.
physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Dry mucous membranes, sunken eyes. Fruity odor on breath.
physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Deep, rapid respirations noted.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, with diffuse tenderness to palpation. No guarding or rebound.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Normal Saline Bolus (1L)
stabilizing.description: After receiving the initial fluid bolus, the patient's heart rate has decreased slightly and blood pressure has improved. He remains lethargic and tachypneic.

improving.description: Several hours after starting the insulin drip and ongoing IV fluids, the patient is more alert, his respirations are less labored, and his metabolic acidosis is correcting.

orderableItems.result: Result: HI (>600 mg/dL)
pH: 7.15, pCO2: 22 mmHg, HCO3: 8 mEq/L. Indicates severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.
Glucose: >1000 mg/dL. Ketones: Large (80 mg/dL).
1 Liter of 0.9% Normal Saline administered IV over 1 hour. Patient's blood pressure improved.
Regular insulin infusion started at 0.1 units/kg/hr. Glucose levels will be monitored hourly.
Endocrinology consulted. Recommends admission to ICU and close monitoring of electrolytes and anion gap.

metadata.title: Ischemic Stroke
teachingPoints: Time is brain; rapid identification and intervention are critical.
Last Known Normal (LKN) is the most critical piece of historical information.
A non-contrast head CT is the first imaging step to rule out hemorrhage.
Blood pressure must be carefully managed (<185/110 mmHg) before administering tPA.
The NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is used to quantify stroke severity and track progression.
For large vessel occlusions (LVO), mechanical thrombectomy may be indicated in addition to or instead of tPA.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of right-sided weakness and facial droop.
initialPresentation.summary: An elderly male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with acute onset of focal neurologic deficits consistent with an acute ischemic stroke.

history.presentIllness: Patient was watching television approximately 45 minutes prior to arrival when his wife noted sudden slurring of his speech and a right-sided facial droop. When he tried to stand up, he collapsed due to weakness in his right arm and leg. The symptoms have been persistent since onset. Last known normal was 1 hour ago.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: 30-pack-year smoking history, quit 10 years ago. Occasional alcohol use.

initial.description: Patient is lying on the stretcher, awake but aphasic and appears distressed. He has a notable right-sided facial droop and is unable to move his right arm or leg.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Alert but with expressive aphasia. Cranial nerves: Right facial droop (CN VII). Motor: Strength 0/5 in right upper and lower extremities, 5/5 in left upper and lower extremities. NIHSS score is 18.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Labetalol 10 mg
stabilizing.description: Blood pressure has been lowered to a safer range for potential thrombolysis. Neurological deficits remain unchanged.

improving.description: Thirty minutes post-thrombolysis, the patient's aphasia is improving and he is beginning to show slight movement in his right leg and arm.

orderableItems.result: 145 mg/dL
No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage. No acute territorial infarct seen. Mild chronic small vessel ischemic changes.
Consultant agrees with diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke. Recommends IV alteplase given patient is within treatment window and has no contraindications. Plan for admission to Stroke Unit.
IV alteplase bolus and infusion started per stroke protocol. Patient monitored closely for any signs of bleeding or angioedema.
Occlusion of the M1 segment of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA). No high-grade stenosis in the carotid or vertebral arteries.

metadata.title: Febrile Seizure
teachingPoints: Simple febrile seizures are generalized, last <15 minutes, and do not recur within 24 hours.
They occur in children aged 6 months to 5 years with a fever >38°C (100.4°F).
The primary goal of evaluation is to identify the source of the fever and rule out serious underlying causes like meningitis.
A thorough physical exam, including checking for meningeal signs, is crucial.
Management is supportive, focusing on antipyretics and parental reassurance.
Extensive workup (labs, imaging, EEG) is not indicated for a first simple febrile seizure.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: An 18-month-old presents after a 2-minute episode of full-body shaking, and has a fever.
initialPresentation.summary: An 18-month-old male with a recent upper respiratory infection presents postictally after a 2-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure in the setting of a high fever, consistent with a simple febrile seizure.

history.presentIllness: Leo's mother reports he has had a runny nose and cough for the past 3 days. Today, his temperature at home was 103.5°F (39.7°C). About 30 minutes prior to arrival, while sitting on the floor, Leo suddenly became stiff, his eyes rolled back, and his entire body started shaking. The episode lasted approximately 2 minutes. Afterwards, he was very sleepy. This is his first such episode.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Born full-term. Immunizations are up-to-date. No family history of epilepsy.

initial.description: The patient is postictal but arousable. He is fussy when stimulated but consoles in his mother's arms. He appears flushed and warm to the touch.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Tympanic membranes are erythematous and bulging bilaterally. Pharynx is erythematous. Anterior fontanelle is soft and flat.
physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Drowsy but moves all four extremities spontaneously. No focal deficits noted. No signs of meningeal irritation.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer Acetaminophen 15 mg/kg PR
stabilizing.description: The patient's fever has started to come down. He is more alert, interactive, and less fussy.

improving.description: After observation and fever reduction, the patient is back to his baseline mental status. He is playful and smiling at his mother.

orderableItems.result: Patient's temperature decreases from 39.7°C to 38.5°C over the next hour. Patient becomes more comfortable and alert.
Patient has a supple neck. Brudzinski's and Kernig's signs are negative. Anterior fontanelle is soft and flat.
95 mg/dL
Consult not indicated for a first simple febrile seizure in a well-appearing, neuro-developmentally normal child.

metadata.title: Aortic Dissection
teachingPoints: Aortic dissection classically presents as a sudden, severe, tearing or ripping chest pain radiating to the back.
A blood pressure differential >20 mmHg between arms is a key physical exam finding.
A widened mediastinum on chest X-ray is suggestive but not diagnostic.
CT Angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis.
Immediate management involves aggressive heart rate and blood pressure control (e.g., with beta-blockers like esmolol).
Stanford Type A dissections (involving the ascending aorta) are a surgical emergency.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of a severe 'tearing' chest pain that radiates to his back.
initialPresentation.summary: A 65-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents with acute, severe tearing chest and back pain and a significant blood pressure discrepancy between his arms, concerning for an aortic dissection.

history.presentIllness: Patient reports the sudden onset of excruciating, 10/10 tearing chest pain approximately 30 minutes ago. The pain began in his central chest and radiated directly through to his back, between his shoulder blades. He feels diaphoretic, nauseous, and profoundly anxious.

initial.description: Patient is in acute distress, pale, and diaphoretic. He is clutching his chest and appears anxious.

physicalExamFindings.General: Anxious, pale, diaphoretic male in obvious severe distress.
physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic with a regular rhythm. A new, soft, early diastolic murmur is auscultated. Blood pressure in right arm is 185/95 mmHg; left arm is 160/85 mmHg.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Labetalol and Esmolol
stabilizing.description: Following aggressive blood pressure and heart rate control, the patient's pain has slightly decreased, and he appears less anxious. He remains hemodynamically tenuous.

improving.description: After successful emergent surgical repair of the ascending aorta, the patient is recovering in the cardiothoracic ICU. He is intubated but hemodynamically stable.

orderableItems.result: Widened mediastinum. Aortic knob is prominent. No evidence of pulmonary edema or pneumothorax.
Diagnostic study reveals a dissection flap originating in the ascending aorta (Stanford Type A) and extending into the brachiocephalic trunk.
Patient's heart rate successfully lowered to a target of 60-80 bpm and systolic blood pressure to a target of 100-120 mmHg.
Cardiothoracic surgery team has evaluated the patient and CT scan and recommends immediate transfer to the operating room for emergent surgical repair.

metadata.title: Acute Myocardial Infarction
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Acute Anterior Wall ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
teachingPoints: Recognize classic symptoms of ACS: crushing substernal chest pain, radiation to arm/jaw, diaphoresis.
A 12-lead EKG should be obtained within 10 minutes of patient arrival.
ST-segment elevation in contiguous leads (e.g., V2-V5) indicates transmural ischemia and is diagnostic of STEMI.
Immediate goals are reperfusion via primary PCI (goal door-to-balloon time <90 minutes) or fibrinolytics.
Initial medical management includes Aspirin, Nitroglycerin, Oxygen (if hypoxic), and Morphine (MONA).
Antiplatelet (e.g., Ticagrelor) and anticoagulant (e.g., Heparin) therapy are crucial components of STEMI care.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: 2 hours of crushing, substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm.
initialPresentation.summary: A middle-aged male with multiple cardiovascular risk factors presents with classic signs and symptoms of acute coronary syndrome, ultimately diagnosed as a STEMI.

history.presentIllness: Patient reports the sudden onset of severe, crushing, substernal chest pain 2 hours prior to arrival. The pain is rated 10/10, radiates to his left arm and jaw, and is associated with significant shortness of breath, nausea, and diaphoresis.

pastMedicalHistory.medications: Lisinopril 20mg daily, Atorvastatin 40mg daily, Metformin 1000mg twice daily
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: 30-pack-year smoking history and occasional alcohol use.

initial.description: Patient is acutely distressed, pale, and diaphoretic, clutching his chest. He appears anxious and is in obvious pain.

physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. S4 gallop noted. No murmurs or rubs.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer MONA therapy (Aspirin, Nitroglycerin, Oxygen, Morphine)
stabilizing.description: Patient's pain has slightly decreased from 10/10 to 7/10 following initial medical management. He remains anxious and tachycardic.

improving.description: Following successful PCI with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery, the patient reports complete resolution of his chest pain.

orderableItems.result: Sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm. ST-segment elevation of 3mm in leads V2-V5. Reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, aVF. Consistent with acute anterior wall STEMI.
Elevated at 4.5 ng/mL (Reference range: <0.04 ng/mL).
Cardiology consulted emergently. Recommends immediate activation of cardiac catheterization lab for primary PCI.
Cardiac catheterization reveals 100% occlusion of the proximal Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery. Successful balloon angioplasty and placement of a drug-eluting stent performed.

metadata.title: Status Epilepticus
teachingPoints: Status epilepticus is a neurological emergency defined as a seizure lasting >5 minutes or ≥2 seizures without recovery of consciousness between them.
Initial management follows ABCs: secure the airway, provide oxygen, and establish IV access.
First-line treatment is a benzodiazepine (e.g., IV Lorazepam).
If seizures persist, a second-line, non-benzodiazepine antiepileptic (e.g., Fosphenytoin, Levetiracetam) should be administered.
Always check a fingerstick glucose, as hypoglycemia can cause seizures.
Non-compliance with anti-epileptic medication is a common cause of status epilepticus.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: A 30-year-old with a known seizure disorder has been actively seizing for over 5 minutes.
initialPresentation.summary: A 30-year-old male with a history of epilepsy, non-compliant with his medication, presents with a continuous generalized tonic-clonic seizure, consistent with status epilepticus.

history.presentIllness: Patient was brought to the emergency department by paramedics. His roommate witnessed a sudden-onset generalized tonic-clonic seizure that has not ceased. The seizure has been continuous for approximately 10 minutes prior to arrival.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day. Occasional alcohol use.

initial.description: Patient is actively having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure on the gurney. He is unresponsive, with rhythmic jerking of all four extremities, upward eye deviation, and frothing at the mouth.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: GCS 3T. Continuous generalized tonic-clonic movements. No response to painful stimuli beyond seizure activity.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Lorazepam 4 mg
stabilizing.description: Seizure activity has briefly attenuated but has not fully ceased. Tonic-clonic movements are now intermittent rather than continuous. Patient remains unresponsive.

improving.description: Seizure activity has completely ceased. The patient is now postictal, drowsy but arousable to painful stimuli. Spontaneous respirations are present and regular.

orderableItems.result: 115 mg/dL
Seizure activity lessens but does not fully resolve. Patient remains unconscious.
Seizure activity ceases. Patient becomes postictal.
< 2.0 mcg/mL (Subtherapeutic, therapeutic range 12-46 mcg/mL)
Neurology recommends continuous EEG monitoring and admission to the Neuro-ICU for further management.

metadata.title: Meningitis
teachingPoints: Bacterial meningitis is a medical emergency with high morbidity and mortality.
Classic triad is fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity.
Look for meningeal signs: Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs.
A petechial rash can be a clue for Neisseria meningitidis.
If meningitis is suspected, administer empiric antibiotics (e.g., Ceftriaxone, Vancomycin) immediately, even before LP if there will be a delay.
Typical CSF findings in bacterial meningitis: high WBC (neutrophil-predominant), high protein, low glucose.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: High fever, severe headache, and neck stiffness.
initialPresentation.summary: A 19-year-old college student presents with a rapid onset of high fever, severe headache, nuchal rigidity, and confusion, consistent with bacterial meningitis.

history.presentIllness: Patient is a 19-year-old male living in a college dormitory who presents with a 24-hour history of progressively worsening symptoms. He initially felt unwell with myalgias. Over the past 12 hours, he developed a severe, diffuse headache (10/10), photophobia, high fever, and significant neck stiffness. His roommate brought him to the ED because he became increasingly lethargic and confused.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Generally healthy. Missed the recommended meningococcal vaccine booster dose at age 16.
pastMedicalHistory.medications: Ibuprofen for headache with minimal relief
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: College sophomore, lives in a dorm.

initial.description: Patient is acutely ill, febrile, lethargic, and oriented only to person. He is lying in a darkened room, complaining of a severe headache.

physicalExamFindings.Neck: Marked nuchal rigidity. Positive Brudzinski's and Kernig's signs.
physicalExamFindings.Skin: Scattered petechiae noted on lower extremities and trunk.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluids (Normal Saline Bolus)
stabilizing.description: After a 2L normal saline bolus, the patient's blood pressure has improved and he appears less diaphoretic. He remains lethargic, febrile, and confused.

improving.description: Several hours after initiation of empiric antibiotics, the patient is more alert and oriented to person and place, and his headache has slightly improved.

orderableItems.result: Opening pressure: 350 mmH2O. Appearance: Turbid. WBC: 2,500/mm3 (95% neutrophils). Glucose: 25 mg/dL. Protein: 220 mg/dL. Gram Stain: Gram-negative diplococci.
Positive. Passive flexion of the neck elicits involuntary flexion of the hips and knees.
Empiric antibiotic therapy initiated. Patient begins to show clinical improvement over the next several hours.
Consultant agrees with empiric coverage and management plan. Recommends droplet precautions.

metadata.title: Acute Manic Episode
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic, Severe
teachingPoints: Mania is characterized by a distinct period of abnormally elevated or irritable mood and increased energy.
Key symptoms include decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, pressured speech, and impulsive/risky behavior.
The primary goal in the acute setting is to ensure safety for the patient and others.
Verbal de-escalation and environmental management should be attempted first.
Pharmacologic intervention with antipsychotics (e.g., Olanzapine) or benzodiazepines is often necessary for agitation.
Rule out substance-induced mania with a urine drug screen.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Erratic behavior, not sleeping for 3 days, and pressured speech.
initialPresentation.summary: A 22-year-old male with no prior psychiatric history presents with pressured speech, grandiosity, and decreased need for sleep, consistent with a first manic episode.

history.presentIllness: The patient's parents report a drastic change over the past week. He has not slept for the last 3 nights, claiming he is 'on the verge of a breakthrough' with a new cryptocurrency. He has been talking incessantly, jumping from topic to topic. He spent $5,000 on high-end computer equipment yesterday, maxing out his credit card. He has been irritable when challenged.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: College student, reports occasional alcohol use, denies illicit drug use.

initial.description: Patient is pacing the room, talking rapidly in a loud voice. He is tangential and difficult to interrupt. Mood is euphoric and expansive, but becomes irritable when redirected.

physicalExamFindings.General: Well-dressed but disheveled, appears energetic with significant psychomotor agitation.
physicalExamFindings.Mental Status Exam: Speech: Pressured, loud, tangential. Mood: Euphoric, irritable. Thought Process: Flight of ideas. Thought Content: Grandiose delusions. Insight/Judgment: Poor.

stabilizing.trigger: Verbal De-escalation & Environmental Management
stabilizing.description: Patient has stopped pacing after being moved to a quiet room but continues to speak rapidly. He is slightly more redirectable but remains grandiose and tangential.

improving.description: 30 minutes post-administration, the patient is sitting on the bed. His speech is slower and more goal-directed. Psychomotor agitation is significantly reduced.

orderableItems.result: Negative for all substances, including amphetamines, cocaine, and PCP.
Medication administered. Agitation and pressured speech begin to improve within 30 minutes.
Consultant agrees with assessment of acute mania. Recommends admission to inpatient psychiatric unit for stabilization and initiation of a mood stabilizer.
Patient moved to a quiet, low-stimulus room. Staff engaged with calm, non-confrontational communication. Patient shows minimal reduction in agitation.

metadata.title: COPD Exacerbation
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Acute Exacerbation of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
teachingPoints: COPD exacerbation is an acute worsening of respiratory symptoms beyond normal day-to-day variations.
Hallmark signs are increased dyspnea, increased sputum volume, and increased sputum purulence.
Management includes supplemental oxygen (cautiously, to avoid hypercapnia), bronchodilators (albuterol/ipratropium), and systemic corticosteroids.
Antibiotics are indicated for moderate to severe exacerbations, especially with increased sputum purulence.
An ABG is useful to assess for hypercapnia and the degree of hypoxemia.
Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (BiPAP) can prevent the need for intubation in patients with hypercapnic respiratory failure.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Worsening shortness of breath and increased cough with sputum.
initialPresentation.summary: A 72-year-old male with a significant smoking history and known COPD presents with acute worsening of dyspnea, productive cough, and wheezing, consistent with a COPD exacerbation.

history.presentIllness: Mr. Davis reports a 3-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath, increased cough, and production of yellow sputum. He has used his home albuterol inhaler more frequently without much relief. He recently had a 'cold' about a week ago.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with emphysema, Hypertension, Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
pastMedicalHistory.medications: Tiotropium, Salmeterol/Fluticasone, Albuterol MDI PRN, Metformin, Lisinopril
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 50 years.

initial.description: Patient is sitting upright, leaning forward, and using accessory muscles to breathe. He is anxious and speaking in short, broken sentences. Diffuse wheezing is audible.

physicalExamFindings.General: Anxious, in moderate respiratory distress, tripoding.
physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Diffuse expiratory wheezing and prolonged expiratory phase. Decreased breath sounds at bases. Accessory muscle use.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer Supplemental Oxygen via Nasal Cannula and Albuterol/Ipratropium Nebulizer
stabilizing.description: After receiving supplemental oxygen and a nebulizer treatment, the patient's oxygen saturation has improved, and his respiratory rate has slightly decreased. He reports feeling a little less breathless.

improving.trigger: Administer Oral Prednisone and IV Azithromycin
improving.description: Several hours after receiving steroids and antibiotics, the patient's work of breathing has significantly improved. Wheezing is less prominent, and he is able to speak in full sentences.

orderableItems.result: pH 7.32, pCO2 58 mmHg, pO2 60 mmHg, HCO3 30 mEq/L. Consistent with acute on chronic respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia.
Hyperinflation of lung fields, flattened diaphragms. No acute infiltrates, effusions, or pneumothorax.
Nebulizer treatment administered. Oxygen saturation improved to 92%.

orderableItems.testName: Administer Oral Prednisone and IV Azithromycin
orderableItems.result: Prednisone 40mg PO and Azithromycin 500mg IV administered. Patient tolerated well.
Respiratory therapist recommends continued nebulizer treatments every 4 hours and close monitoring of oxygenation.

metadata.title: Ankle Fracture
teachingPoints: Ankle fractures are common injuries, often resulting from inversion or eversion mechanisms.
The Ottawa Ankle Rules can help determine the need for radiography.
A trimalleolar fracture involves the medial, lateral, and posterior malleoli and is inherently unstable.
A thorough neurovascular exam distal to the injury is critical.
Initial management includes pain control, reduction of any dislocation, and immobilization with a splint.
Unstable ankle fractures, like trimalleolar fractures, typically require surgical intervention (ORIF).

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Severe right ankle pain and inability to bear weight after a fall.
initialPresentation.summary: A 25-year-old male presents with acute right ankle pain, swelling, and inability to bear weight after an inversion injury, concerning for an ankle fracture.

history.presentIllness: Mr. White was playing basketball approximately 1 hour ago when he landed awkwardly on his right foot, causing an inversion injury to his ankle. He experienced immediate, severe pain, rated 9/10, and was unable to bear any weight on the affected leg. The ankle rapidly swelled.

initial.description: Patient is sitting on the gurney with his right leg elevated. His right ankle is visibly swollen and deformed. He is in significant pain.

physicalExamFindings.Right Ankle: Significant swelling and ecchymosis around the lateral malleolus. Tenderness to palpation over the distal fibula. Obvious deformity. Unable to bear weight. Distal pulses and sensation are intact.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fentanyl and Apply Splint
stabilizing.description: After receiving pain medication and having a temporary splint applied, the patient's pain has decreased. The ankle is immobilized, and he appears more comfortable.

improving.description: Post-operatively, the patient is recovering well. His pain is controlled, and the surgical site is clean, dry, and intact. He is educated on non-weight bearing status.

orderableItems.testName: Right Ankle X-ray (AP, Lateral, Mortise views)
orderableItems.result: Trimalleolar fracture of the right ankle with displacement. Fracture of the lateral malleolus, medial malleolus, and posterior malleolus. Talus is laterally displaced.

orderableItems.testName: Administer IV Fentanyl and Apply Splint
orderableItems.result: Fentanyl 50 mcg IV administered. Posterior splint applied to the right ankle. Pain reduced, ankle immobilized.
Orthopedic surgeon consulted. Agrees with diagnosis of unstable trimalleolar fracture and recommends urgent Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF).
Successful ORIF of the right trimalleolar fracture performed. Hardware placed to stabilize the fracture fragments.

metadata.title: Community-Acquired Pneumonia
teachingPoints: CAP is an acute infection of the pulmonary parenchyma in a patient who has not been recently hospitalized.
Classic symptoms include fever, cough with purulent sputum, and dyspnea.
Physical exam findings may include crackles, egophony, and dullness to percussion over the affected area.
A chest X-ray showing an infiltrate is required to confirm the diagnosis.
Severity can be assessed using scores like CURB-65 to determine disposition (outpatient vs. inpatient).
Treatment for inpatient CAP typically involves a beta-lactam (e.g., Ceftriaxone) plus a macrolide (e.g., Azithromycin).

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: 3-day history of productive cough, fever, and malaise.
initialPresentation.summary: An elderly male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with fever, productive cough, and tachypnea, with physical exam findings and imaging consistent with community-acquired pneumonia.

history.presentIllness: The patient presents with a 3-day history of worsening cough, fever, and generalized weakness. The cough is productive of thick, yellow-green sputum. He has experienced subjective fevers, chills, and sweats. He also reports some mild shortness of breath with exertion and pleuritic right-sided chest pain.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Smokes 1 pack per day for 40 years, occasional alcohol use.

initial.description: The patient is febrile, tachycardic, and tachypneic. He appears fatigued but is alert and oriented.

physicalExamFindings.General: Appears ill and fatigued, using accessory muscles for breathing.
physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Decreased breath sounds, crackles, and egophony over the right lower lung base. No wheezes.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer Supplemental Oxygen via Nasal Cannula
stabilizing.description: After receiving supplemental oxygen, the patient's oxygen saturation improves, and his respiratory rate decreases slightly. He reports feeling a little less short of breath.

improving.description: Several hours after the first dose of antibiotics, the patient's fever begins to resolve. He appears more comfortable, and his vital signs are trending towards normal.

orderableItems.result: WBC: 16.5 x 10^9/L (High), with 85% neutrophils.
Findings consistent with a right lower lobe consolidation/infiltrate. No significant pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
First dose of Ceftriaxone 1g IV and Azithromycin 500mg IV administered. Patient tolerated well.
Pending. Preliminary result at 24 hours: No growth.

metadata.title: Preeclampsia with Severe Features
teachingPoints: Preeclampsia is new-onset hypertension (SBP ≥140 or DBP ≥90) after 20 weeks of gestation with proteinuria or signs of end-organ damage.
Severe features include SBP ≥160 or DBP ≥110, thrombocytopenia, impaired liver function, severe RUQ pain, renal insufficiency, pulmonary edema, or new-onset headache/visual disturbances.
The definitive treatment for preeclampsia is delivery of the fetus and placenta.
Magnesium sulfate is administered for seizure prophylaxis in patients with severe features.
Acute, severe hypertension should be treated with IV labetalol or hydralazine to prevent stroke.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Severe headache and blurry vision at 34 weeks gestation.
initialPresentation.summary: A 32-year-old G1P0 at 34 weeks gestation presents with new-onset severe headache, visual changes, and severely elevated blood pressure, consistent with preeclampsia with severe features.

history.presentIllness: Patient presents to the labor and delivery unit with a 12-hour history of a persistent, severe frontal headache that is not relieved by acetaminophen. She also reports seeing 'flashing lights' and has some blurry vision. She has noticed increased swelling in her hands and face over the past two days. She denies contractions, vaginal bleeding, or leakage of fluid. Fetal movements are present and normal for her.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Uncomplicated pregnancy until now. No history of hypertension.
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Married, non-smoker, denies alcohol or drug use.

initial.description: Patient is alert but anxious, complaining of a severe headache. She has 3+ pitting edema in her lower extremities and facial puffiness.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Alert and oriented x3. Hyperreflexia (3+ patellar reflexes) with 2 beats of clonus bilaterally.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Gravid, non-tender. Fundal height consistent with dates. Fetal heart tones in 140s.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Labetalol 20 mg
stabilizing.description: After IV labetalol, the patient's blood pressure has decreased to a safer range. Her headache is slightly improved, but she remains hypertensive.

improving.description: With the magnesium sulfate infusion running, the patient's reflexes have decreased to 2+ and she has no further clonus. She is being prepared for induction of labor.

orderableItems.result: Urine dipstick shows 3+ protein. Urine protein/creatinine ratio is 1.2 mg/mg (significant proteinuria).
Platelets: 85,000/uL (low). Hgb: 11.5 g/dL, WBC: 9.8 x 10^9/L.
AST: 150 U/L (high), ALT: 125 U/L (high). Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL (high).
Blood pressure decreased to 155/102 mmHg. Patient tolerated well.
4g IV loading dose followed by a 2g/hr maintenance infusion started for seizure prophylaxis.
Attending obstetrician at bedside. Plan is to stabilize blood pressure, administer magnesium and corticosteroids (for fetal lung maturity), and proceed with induction of labor.

metadata.title: Septic Shock from Urosepsis
teachingPoints: Recognize septic shock criteria: suspected infection, vasopressor requirement to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg, and lactate >2 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation.
Time is critical: initiate sepsis bundles including blood cultures, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and fluid resuscitation within the first hour.
Norepinephrine is the first-line vasopressor for septic shock.
Source control is a key component of management; in urosepsis, this may involve relieving an obstruction.
Interpret urinalysis with microscopy to identify signs of infection (leukocyte esterase, nitrites, pyuria).
In elderly patients, altered mental status may be the primary presenting sign of severe infection.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Lethargy and confusion.
initialPresentation.summary: An 82-year-old male from a nursing home with an indwelling Foley catheter presents with acute confusion, hypotension, and tachycardia, consistent with septic shock from a urinary source.

history.presentIllness: Mr. Miller was brought in by ambulance after nursing home staff noted he became acutely lethargic and confused over the past 12 hours. He has been less responsive and has had poor oral intake. He has a chronic indwelling Foley catheter for urinary retention due to BPH. The nursing staff noted his urine in the catheter bag appeared cloudy and foul-smelling this morning. He has had subjective fevers and chills.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH), Hypertension, Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, Mild Dementia
pastMedicalHistory.medications: Tamsulosin 0.4mg daily, Metformin 500mg BID, Lisinopril 10mg daily
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Retired, lives in a skilled nursing facility.

initial.description: Patient is lethargic, responding only to painful stimuli. He is febrile, tachycardic, and hypotensive. His skin is warm and flushed.

physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. Bounding pulses. Capillary refill < 2 seconds.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, non-distended, with mild suprapubic tenderness. Foley catheter in place with purulent urine.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer 30 mL/kg IV Crystalloid Fluid Bolus
stabilizing.description: After the initial fluid bolus, the patient's heart rate has slightly decreased, but he remains hypotensive. He is slightly more responsive, moaning to verbal stimuli.

improving.description: With the initiation of vasopressor support and broad-spectrum antibiotics, the patient's blood pressure has stabilized (MAP > 65 mmHg). He is more arousable and his lactate is beginning to clear.

orderableItems.result: Appearance: Turbid. Leukocyte Esterase: Large. Nitrites: Positive. WBC: >100/hpf. Bacteria: Large.
4.5 mmol/L (Elevated).

orderableItems.testName: Blood Cultures x2 and Urine Culture
orderableItems.result: Cultures obtained. Pending results. (Later positive for E. coli).
First dose of broad-spectrum antibiotic administered after cultures were drawn.
Norepinephrine started at 5 mcg/min and titrated to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg.
Urology consulted for management of chronic catheter and assessment for potential obstruction. Recommends catheter exchange and renal ultrasound.

metadata.title: Kawasaki Disease
teachingPoints: Kawasaki disease is a medium-vessel vasculitis of childhood, primarily affecting children under 5 years old.
Diagnosis is clinical, based on fever for ≥5 days plus at least 4 of 5 criteria (CRASH: Conjunctivitis, Rash, Adenopathy, Strawberry tongue, Hand/foot changes).
The most serious complication is the development of coronary artery aneurysms.
Treatment with high-dose Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG) and aspirin is critical to reduce the risk of aneurysms.
An echocardiogram is mandatory at the time of diagnosis and in follow-up to assess for coronary artery involvement.
Consider Kawasaki disease in any child with prolonged, unexplained fever.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Fever for 6 days, rash, and red eyes.
initialPresentation.summary: A 3-year-old female presents with a prolonged high fever, bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis, a polymorphous rash, and cervical lymphadenopathy, meeting clinical criteria for Kawasaki Disease.

history.presentIllness: Chloe has had a high fever (up to 40°C / 104°F) for the past 6 days, unresponsive to acetaminophen and ibuprofen. Over the last 3 days, her parents noted her eyes became very red but without any discharge. She developed a blotchy red rash on her trunk and extremities, and her lips became red and cracked. She has been extremely irritable and has a decreased appetite. They also noticed a lump on the left side of her neck.

pastMedicalHistory.medications: Acetaminophen and Ibuprofen PRN for fever
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Up-to-date on all immunizations. Attends daycare.

initial.description: Patient is febrile and extremely irritable, crying inconsolably. She has a visible rash and conjunctival injection.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Bilateral, non-exudative conjunctival injection. Dry, fissured, erythematous lips and an erythematous oropharynx ('strawberry tongue').
physicalExamFindings.Neck: A single, tender, non-fluctuant left anterior cervical lymph node measuring 2 cm.
physicalExamFindings.Skin: Diffuse, polymorphous, maculopapular rash on the trunk and extremities. Mild erythema and swelling of hands and feet.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluids and Antipyretics
stabilizing.description: After receiving IV fluids for hydration and scheduled antipyretics, the patient's fever has temporarily decreased. She remains irritable but is no longer crying continuously.

improving.description: Within 24 hours of completing the IVIG infusion, the patient has defervesced. Her rash and conjunctivitis are resolving, and her irritability has markedly improved. She is starting to take oral fluids.

orderableItems.result: WBC: 18.5 x 10^9/L (leukocytosis), Hgb: 10.8 g/dL (normocytic anemia), Platelets: 550 x 10^9/L (thrombocytosis).
CRP: 150 mg/L (high), ESR: 95 mm/hr (high).
Normal left ventricular function. No coronary artery ectasia or aneurysms noted at baseline. Mild pericardial effusion.
IVIG 2 g/kg administered over 12 hours. Patient tolerated the infusion well.
High-dose aspirin (80 mg/kg/day) initiated for its anti-inflammatory effects.
Consultant agrees with the diagnosis of Kawasaki Disease and the treatment plan. Recommends close follow-up and repeat echocardiogram in 2 weeks.

metadata.title: Perforated Peptic Ulcer
teachingPoints: A perforated peptic ulcer is a surgical emergency that presents as a sudden onset of severe, diffuse abdominal pain.
Patients often have a history of PUD, H. pylori infection, or chronic NSAID use.
Physical exam reveals signs of peritonitis: a rigid, board-like abdomen, guarding, and rebound tenderness.
An upright chest X-ray is a crucial first imaging step to look for free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum).
Management involves immediate fluid resuscitation, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and emergent surgical intervention (e.g., Graham patch).
Post-operatively, patients require acid suppression therapy and treatment for H. pylori if present.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain.
initialPresentation.summary: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic NSAID use for arthritis presents with an acute abdomen, with examination and imaging findings consistent with a perforated peptic ulcer.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports the abrupt onset of excruciating, generalized abdominal pain approximately 4 hours ago. He describes the pain as a 'burning' sensation that is constant and severe (10/10). Any movement, including breathing, exacerbates the pain. He has not had any nausea or vomiting. He has a history of taking high doses of ibuprofen daily for chronic knee pain.

pastMedicalHistory.medications: Ibuprofen 800mg three times daily, Lisinopril 20mg daily
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Smokes 1 pack per day for 30 years.

initial.description: Patient is lying completely still on the gurney with his knees flexed. He is pale, diaphoretic, and in severe distress.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Distended, tympanitic, and rigid ('board-like'). Severe tenderness to light palpation throughout all quadrants. Involuntary guarding and rebound tenderness are present. Bowel sounds are absent.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluids and Broad-Spectrum Antibiotics
stabilizing.description: After fluid resuscitation and initiation of antibiotics, the patient's tachycardia and hypotension have improved. He remains in severe pain with a rigid abdomen.

improving.description: Post-operatively, the patient is recovering in the ICU. His abdomen is soft, and his pain is controlled with a PCA. He is hemodynamically stable.

orderableItems.result: Large amount of free air (pneumoperitoneum) visualized under both hemidiaphragms.
WBC: 17.8 x 10^9/L with a left shift.
3.8 mmol/L (Elevated).
Broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage for gut flora initiated.
General surgery consulted emergently. Recommends immediate exploratory laparotomy for repair of perforated viscus.
A 2 cm perforated ulcer on the anterior duodenum was identified and repaired with a Graham patch. The abdomen was thoroughly irrigated. Patient tolerated the procedure well.

metadata.title: Stroke with Large Vessel Occlusion
teachingPoints: Large Vessel Occlusion (LVO) strokes often present with severe deficits (high NIHSS score), including gaze deviation, profound hemiplegia, and neglect or aphasia.
A non-contrast head CT is the first step to rule out hemorrhage, but CTA is required to identify the vessel occlusion.
Time is critical. Patients with LVO may be candidates for mechanical thrombectomy, which has a longer treatment window than IV tPA for select patients.
The decision for tPA vs. thrombectomy vs. both depends on time from LKN, contraindications, and institutional protocols.
Multidisciplinary coordination between ED, Neurology, and Interventional Radiology/Neurosurgery is essential for rapid treatment.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden inability to speak or move the left side of her body.
initialPresentation.summary: A 68-year-old female with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with acute onset of global aphasia and dense left hemiplegia, with a high NIHSS score concerning for a large vessel occlusion stroke.

history.presentIllness: The patient was eating breakfast with her husband 90 minutes ago when she suddenly dropped her spoon, developed a left facial droop, and was unable to speak or move her left side. Her husband immediately called 911. Her symptoms have not changed since onset. Last known normal was 90 minutes ago.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Atrial Fibrillation (on aspirin only), Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia

initial.description: Patient is awake but appears distressed and frightened. She has a dense left hemiplegia and is unable to follow commands or speak. Her eyes are deviated to the right.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Alert but with global aphasia and left-sided neglect. Eyes are deviated to the right. Left facial droop. Motor strength 0/5 in left upper and lower extremities, 5/5 on the right. NIHSS score is 22.

stabilizing.trigger: Obtain Emergent Head CT/CTA
stabilizing.description: Imaging has been completed. The patient's neurological deficits remain profound. She is being prepared for intervention.

improving.description: Immediately following successful revascularization, the patient's gaze deviation has resolved. She is beginning to move her left leg and is attempting to speak. Her NIHSS score has improved to 12.

orderableItems.result: No evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage. Subtle loss of grey-white differentiation in the right MCA territory.

orderableItems.testName: CT Angiography of Head and Neck
orderableItems.result: Complete occlusion of the M1 segment of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA).
Stroke team at bedside. Confirms LVO. Patient is a candidate for mechanical thrombectomy. IV tPA is held due to imminent endovascular procedure.
Successful removal of the thrombus from the right MCA with a stent retriever. TICI 3 (complete) reperfusion achieved.
Patient admitted for close hemodynamic and neurological monitoring post-thrombectomy.

metadata.title: Serotonin Syndrome
teachingPoints: Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by excessive serotonergic activity.
It is often caused by the combination of multiple serotonergic agents (e.g., SSRIs, MAOIs, triptans, tramadol).

The clinical triad includes: altered mental status (agitation, confusion), autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, hyperthermia), and neuromuscular abnormalities (clonus, hyperreflexia, tremor).
Clonus (especially ocular or inducible) and hyperreflexia in the lower extremities are key diagnostic findings.
Management is primarily supportive: discontinuation of offending agents, IV fluids, and benzodiazepines for agitation and hyperthermia.
Severe cases may require sedation, intubation, and treatment with cyproheptadine.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Agitation, sweating, and tremors.
initialPresentation.summary: A 24-year-old female with a history of depression and migraines presents with acute agitation, autonomic instability, and clonus after starting a new medication, consistent with serotonin syndrome.

history.presentIllness: The patient was brought to the ED by her partner due to a 6-hour history of worsening agitation, confusion, and profuse sweating. She has been tremulous and restless. Her partner reports she was recently prescribed tramadol for pain by her dentist, in addition to her usual medications for depression and migraines. She took her first dose of tramadol this morning.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Graduate student, denies illicit drug use.

initial.description: Patient is agitated, diaphoretic, and tremulous on the gurney. She is disoriented to time and is unable to focus.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Disoriented and confused. Spontaneous clonus of the ankles is present. Hyperreflexia (3+) in lower extremities. Tremor in all extremities.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Lorazepam 2 mg
stabilizing.description: After receiving a benzodiazepine, the patient's agitation and tremors have decreased. She is calmer but remains confused and tachycardic.

improving.trigger: Discontinue all serotonergic agents and provide supportive care
improving.description: After 12 hours of supportive care with IV fluids and benzodiazepines, the patient's vital signs have normalized. Her mental status has cleared, and the clonus has resolved.

orderableItems.result: Inducible and spontaneous clonus present at the ankles.
Elevated at 1,500 U/L, indicating muscle rigidity and breakdown.
Patient's agitation and muscle rigidity decrease.

Consultant confirms diagnosis of serotonin syndrome. Recommends holding all serotonergic agents and providing supportive care. Will assist with re-initiating a safe medication regimen upon resolution.
Pharmacist reviews medication list, identifies the drug-drug interaction between sertraline and tramadol, and provides education on avoiding serotonergic combinations.

metadata.title: Gestational Diabetes
teachingPoints: Gestational diabetes (GDM) is diabetes diagnosed in the second or third trimester of pregnancy that was not clearly overt diabetes prior to gestation.
Universal screening is typically performed at 24-28 weeks gestation with a glucose challenge test.
Initial management focuses on dietary modification, exercise, and blood glucose self-monitoring.
If glycemic targets are not met with lifestyle changes, pharmacotherapy (e.g., insulin, metformin) is initiated.
GDM increases the risk of fetal macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and preeclampsia.
Women with GDM are at a significantly increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes later in life and require postpartum screening.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Routine prenatal visit at 26 weeks with abnormal glucose screen.
initialPresentation.summary: A 34-year-old G2P1 at 26 weeks gestation is found to have an abnormal 1-hour glucose challenge test, leading to a diagnosis of gestational diabetes.

history.presentIllness: The patient presents for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well and has no specific complaints. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated to date. As part of routine screening, she underwent a 1-hour 50g glucose challenge test one week ago, and the result was elevated.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Married, works as an accountant. No smoking or alcohol use.

initial.description: Patient is well-appearing and in no distress. Her fundal height is appropriate for gestational age.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Gravid, non-tender. Fundal height 26 cm. Fetal heart tones in 140s.

stabilizing.trigger: Perform 3-hour Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT)
stabilizing.description: The patient has completed the 3-hour OGTT. The results confirm the diagnosis of gestational diabetes.

improving.trigger: Initiate dietary counseling and self-monitoring of blood glucose
improving.description: After one week of lifestyle modification, the patient's self-monitored blood glucose levels are consistently within the target range. She feels well and is motivated to continue the plan.

orderableItems.result: 155 mg/dL (Abnormal, cutoff is typically 130-140 mg/dL).
Fasting: 98 (high), 1-hr: 195 (high), 2-hr: 165 (high), 3-hr: 130 (normal). Two or more abnormal values are diagnostic of GDM.
Patient receives counseling on a diabetic diet and instruction on how to use a glucometer to check blood sugar four times daily.
Patient begins checking fasting and 2-hour postprandial blood sugars. Initial logs show good glycemic control with diet.

metadata.title: Open Tibial Fracture
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Open Tibial Shaft Fracture (Gustilo-Anderson Type II)
teachingPoints: An open fracture is a surgical emergency due to the high risk of infection (osteomyelitis).
Initial management includes a thorough neurovascular assessment, gross decontamination, sterile dressing application, splinting, and prompt administration of IV antibiotics and a tetanus booster.
The Gustilo-Anderson classification is used to grade open fractures and guide antibiotic choice and prognosis.
Definitive management involves surgical irrigation and debridement followed by fracture fixation (e.g., intramedullary nailing).
Compartment syndrome is a major potential complication of high-energy tibial fractures.
Early involvement of physiotherapy is crucial for restoring function and mobility.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Severe left leg pain and deformity after a motorcycle crash.
initialPresentation.summary: A 28-year-old male presents as a trauma activation after a motorcycle accident with a deformed, painful left lower leg and a visible wound with bone exposed, consistent with an open tibial fracture.

history.presentIllness: The patient was riding his motorcycle at approximately 40 mph when a car pulled out in front of him, causing a collision. He was thrown from the bike and reports immediate, severe pain and deformity in his left leg. He denies loss of consciousness. Paramedics applied a traction splint and started an IV en route.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Works as a mechanic, smokes cigarettes, drinks alcohol socially.

initial.description: Patient is on a backboard, awake and alert, in severe pain. His left lower leg is grossly deformed with a 3 cm laceration over the anterior tibia, through which bone is visible.

physicalExamFindings.Left Lower Extremity: Grossly deformed tibia. 3 cm transverse laceration with exposed bone. Distal pulses (dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial) are 1+ and dopplerable. Sensation is intact to light touch. Compartments are soft.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Cefazolin and Tetanus Toxoid
stabilizing.description: After pain control, splinting, and initial antibiotic administration, the patient is more comfortable. The wound has been covered with a sterile dressing. He is awaiting imaging.

improving.description: The patient is now post-operative day 1. His pain is well-controlled. His leg is in a splint, and his neurovascular status is intact. He is awaiting evaluation by physiotherapy.

orderableItems.result: Comminuted, displaced fracture of the mid-shaft of the tibia and a simple fracture of the fibula.
First-generation cephalosporin administered for gram-positive coverage as per open fracture protocol.
Orthopedics at bedside. Recommends urgent irrigation and debridement with intramedullary nailing.
Patient underwent successful surgical fixation of the tibial fracture.
Consult placed for post-operative day 1 evaluation for non-weight bearing mobilization and rehabilitation planning.

metadata.title: Flash Pulmonary Edema
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Acute Decompensated Heart Failure (Flash Pulmonary Edema)
teachingPoints: Flash pulmonary edema is a rapid onset of respiratory failure due to fluid accumulation in the lungs, often secondary to acute cardiac dysfunction.
It is frequently caused by hypertensive emergency or acute myocardial ischemia leading to severe diastolic dysfunction.
Patients present in extremis with severe dyspnea, hypoxia, and often pink, frothy sputum.
Management requires aggressive afterload reduction (e.g., nitroglycerin infusion) and positive pressure ventilation (BiPAP or intubation).
Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) showing diffuse B-lines is highly suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
Diuretics are important but may be less effective initially if blood pressure is tenuous; the priority is reducing afterload.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden, severe shortness of breath.
initialPresentation.summary: A 72-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents with the abrupt onset of severe respiratory distress, hypoxia, and diffuse crackles on exam, consistent with flash pulmonary edema.

history.presentIllness: The patient was feeling well until approximately 30 minutes ago when she experienced the sudden onset of profound shortness of breath while sitting in a chair. She is unable to speak in full sentences and feels like she is 'drowning.' She has a cough productive of pink, frothy sputum. She denies chest pain but feels a sense of panic.

initial.description: Patient is sitting bolt upright, gasping for air. She is diaphoretic, anxious, and using accessory muscles. Pink, frothy sputum is visible on her lips.

physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Diffuse, coarse crackles heard throughout all lung fields.
physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, with an audible S3 gallop. Jugular venous distention is present.

stabilizing.trigger: Initiate Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure (BiPAP)
stabilizing.description: With BiPAP, the patient's work of breathing has decreased, and her oxygen saturation has improved. She remains hypertensive and tachycardic.

improving.description: After initiating a nitroglycerin drip for aggressive afterload reduction, the patient's blood pressure has decreased, and her respiratory distress is rapidly improving. The crackles on her lung exam are less prominent.

orderableItems.result: Cardiac views show a hyperdynamic left ventricle. Lung views show diffuse, bilateral, confluent B-lines (>3 per intercostal space).
Severe pulmonary vascular congestion, bilateral interstitial edema, and small pleural effusions (batwing appearance).
Patient placed on BiPAP with settings IPAP 12, EPAP 6. Work of breathing and oxygenation improve.
Nitroglycerin drip started and titrated to reduce blood pressure and afterload, leading to rapid clinical improvement.
High dose of IV furosemide given to promote diuresis.
Cardiology consulted. Recommends admission to Cardiac ICU for continued management and investigation into the underlying cause of the acute decompensation.

metadata.title: PCP in Undiagnosed HIV
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Pneumocystis Pneumonia (PCP) in a patient with newly diagnosed HIV/AIDS
teachingPoints: Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV (CD4 count <200 cells/mm³).
Patients typically present with a subacute onset of fever, non-productive cough, and progressive dyspnea.
Classic lab findings include elevated LDH and hypoxia that worsens with exertion.
Chest X-ray often shows bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates.
Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying Pneumocystis jirovecii in induced sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid.
Treatment is with high-dose Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). Corticosteroids are added if PaO2 is <70 mmHg or the A-a gradient is >35 mmHg.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for 3 weeks.
initialPresentation.summary: A 38-year-old male with no known past medical history presents with subacute dyspnea, non-productive cough, and significant hypoxemia, found to have PCP pneumonia as the initial presentation of AIDS.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports a 3-week history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and a persistent, dry cough. Over the past week, he has become dyspneic even at rest. He has also experienced subjective fevers, night sweats, and an unintentional 20-pound weight loss over the last 3 months. He denies chest pain or sick contacts.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Works in sales. Reports a history of male and female sexual partners and inconsistent condom use.

initial.description: Patient is thin, appears chronically ill, and is in moderate respiratory distress. He is tachypneic and speaking in short sentences.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Oral thrush (candidiasis) is noted on the tongue and palate.
physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally despite significant hypoxia.

stabilizing.trigger: Apply High-Flow Nasal Cannula
stabilizing.description: With high-flow oxygen support, the patient's oxygen saturation has improved, and his work of breathing has decreased. He remains tachypneic.

improving.description: After 48 hours of treatment, the patient's oxygen requirement is decreasing, and his respiratory rate has normalized. He is afebrile and reports subjective improvement in his breathing.

orderableItems.result: Diffuse, bilateral, interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region.
Elevated at 650 U/L.
Reactive (Positive).

orderableItems.testName: CD4 Count and HIV Viral Load
orderableItems.result: CD4 Count: 45 cells/mm³. Viral Load: 250,000 copies/mL.
High-dose TMP-SMX and corticosteroids (due to severe hypoxia) were started.
Consultant confirms diagnosis and management plan. Will manage initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART) upon clinical improvement and counsel the patient.

metadata.title: Thyroid Storm
teachingPoints: Thyroid storm is a life-threatening, exaggerated state of hyperthyroidism, often precipitated by a stressor (e.g., infection, surgery) in a patient with underlying thyrotoxicosis.
Clinical features include high fever, tachycardia, CNS dysfunction (agitation, delirium), and cardiovascular collapse.
Diagnosis is clinical, supported by thyroid function tests (suppressed TSH, elevated free T4/T3).

Management is a multi-pronged approach: 1) Beta-blockers for symptom control, 2) Thionamides (PTU or methimazole) to block new hormone synthesis, 3) Iodine solution to block hormone release, and 4) Corticosteroids to reduce peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
PTU is often preferred in thyroid storm as it also blocks peripheral T4 to T3 conversion.
Identify and treat the underlying precipitating event.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: High fever, palpitations, and confusion.
initialPresentation.summary: A 42-year-old female with a history of Graves' disease and recent medication non-compliance presents with hyperthermia, tachyarrhythmia, and delirium, consistent with thyroid storm.

history.presentIllness: The patient is brought in by her family for acute confusion and agitation. Over the past 24 hours, she developed a high fever, profuse sweating, and severe palpitations. She has been extremely agitated and delirious. Her family reports she has a history of Graves' disease but stopped taking her methimazole about a month ago because she 'felt better.' She has also had a cough and congestion for the past few days.

initial.description: Patient is agitated, delirious, and diaphoretic. She is tremulous and has a palpable goiter.

physicalExamFindings.Neck: Diffusely enlarged, non-tender goiter with an audible bruit.
physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, irregularly irregular rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation.
physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Agitated, disoriented. Fine tremor of outstretched hands. Hyperreflexia.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Propranolol and Cooling Measures
stabilizing.description: After administration of a beta-blocker and application of cooling blankets, the patient's heart rate has decreased, and her temperature is slowly coming down. She remains agitated.

improving.trigger: Administer PTU, Iodine Solution, and Hydrocortisone
improving.description: Several hours after initiating multi-modal therapy, the patient's sensorium is improving. She is now drowsy but oriented. Her heart rate is controlled, and she is afebrile.

orderableItems.testName: Thyroid Function Tests (TSH, Free T4, Free T3)
orderableItems.result: TSH: <0.01 mIU/L (suppressed). Free T4: 6.8 ng/dL (high). Free T3: 22 pg/mL (high).
Atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response at 165 bpm.
IV propranolol administered to control heart rate and adrenergic symptoms.
Loading dose of PTU given via NG tube to block thyroid hormone synthesis.
IV hydrocortisone given to reduce peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and treat potential adrenal insufficiency.
Endocrinology consulted emergently. Agrees with diagnosis and guides the complex, timed medication regimen. Recommends admission to ICU.

metadata.title: Rhabdomyolysis and AKI
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Rhabdomyolysis with subsequent Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
teachingPoints: Rhabdomyolysis is the breakdown of skeletal muscle, releasing myoglobin and other intracellular contents into the circulation.
Common causes include trauma, prolonged immobilization, extreme exertion, and certain medications/toxins.
The classic triad is myalgias, weakness, and dark (tea-colored) urine, but it is not always present.
Diagnosis is confirmed by a markedly elevated creatine kinase (CK) level, typically >5 times the upper limit of normal.
Myoglobin is nephrotoxic; rhabdomyolysis can lead to acute kidney injury (AKI).
Management is centered on aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation to maintain renal perfusion and flush out myoglobin.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Found on the floor by family.
initialPresentation.summary: A 78-year-old male is brought to the ED after being found on the floor, where he may have been for up to 24 hours. He presents with dehydration, confusion, and laboratory evidence of rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.

history.presentIllness: The patient was found on the floor of his apartment by his son, who had not heard from him in a day. The patient is confused and unable to provide a clear history, but it is estimated he was down for 12-24 hours. He complains of diffuse muscle pain and is unable to stand. His son notes his urine in the toilet was very dark.

initial.description: Patient is lying on the gurney, appears dehydrated with dry mucous membranes. He is confused and oriented only to person.

physicalExamFindings.Musculoskeletal: Diffuse tenderness to palpation of large muscle groups, especially gluteal and thigh muscles. No signs of trauma.
physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Alert but confused (A&O x1). Moves all extremities but with weakness.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer 1L IV Normal Saline Bolus
stabilizing.description: After the initial fluid bolus, the patient's heart rate and blood pressure have improved. He remains confused.

improving.description: After several hours of continuous IV fluids, the patient has begun to produce urine, which is gradually clearing. His CK levels are trending down, and his creatinine is stabilizing.

orderableItems.result: 45,000 U/L (Markedly elevated).
BUN: 50 mg/dL, Creatinine: 3.2 mg/dL (AKI). Potassium: 5.8 mEq/L (hyperkalemia). Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL (hypocalcemia).
Color: Dark brown. Blood: Large. RBCs on microscopy: 0-2/hpf. (Myoglobinuria causes a positive heme result on dipstick without actual red blood cells).
Normal Saline started at 200 mL/hr with a goal urine output of >100 mL/hr.
Nephrology consulted for management of AKI and electrolyte abnormalities. Recommends continuing aggressive hydration and monitoring for indications for dialysis.

metadata.title: Bronchiolitis
teachingPoints: Bronchiolitis is a viral lower respiratory tract infection, most commonly caused by RSV, primarily affecting children under 2 years old.
It typically begins with URI symptoms (rhinorrhea, congestion) and progresses to inflammation of the small airways, causing wheezing and crackles.
The diagnosis is clinical; routine lab work and chest X-rays are not recommended for typical cases.
Management is entirely supportive, focusing on hydration and respiratory support (e.g., nasal suctioning, supplemental oxygen if needed).
Bronchodilators and corticosteroids have not been shown to be effective and are not recommended.
Indications for admission include hypoxia, dehydration, or significant respiratory distress (nasal flaring, retractions, tachypnea).

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Cough, fast breathing, and poor feeding.
initialPresentation.summary: A 4-month-old infant presents with a 3-day history of upper respiratory symptoms that have progressed to tachypnea, wheezing, and increased work of breathing, consistent with bronchiolitis.

history.presentIllness: Kevin's parents report he developed a runny nose and cough 3 days ago. Over the past 24 hours, his breathing has become faster and more labored. He has an audible wheeze and is having difficulty feeding, taking only half of his usual bottle amount. He has had fewer wet diapers today. His older sibling recently had a 'cold.'

initial.description: Infant is awake but fussy. He has prominent nasal flaring, subcostal and intercostal retractions, and audible wheezing.

physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Tachypneic with diffuse expiratory wheezing and fine inspiratory crackles throughout both lungs. Significant subcostal retractions.

stabilizing.trigger: Nasal Suctioning and Supplemental Oxygen
stabilizing.description: After deep nasal suctioning to clear the upper airway and placement on supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula, the infant's work of breathing has improved, and his oxygen saturation has increased.

improving.description: After 24 hours of supportive care including oxygen, nasal suctioning, and IV fluids for hydration, the infant is in less respiratory distress and is beginning to show interest in feeding again.

orderableItems.result: Large amount of thick mucus cleared from the nares, resulting in a temporary improvement in work of breathing.
Oxygen started at 1 L/min via nasal cannula. Saturation improves from 91% to 95%.
Hyperinflation and peribronchial cuffing. No focal consolidation. (Note: Not routinely indicated but often performed).
Positive for Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). (Note: Does not change management but useful for cohorting).
Patient admitted for continued respiratory support, hydration, and monitoring.

metadata.title: Ruptured Ectopic Pregnancy
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Ruptured Ectopic Pregnancy with Hemorrhagic Shock
teachingPoints: Consider ectopic pregnancy in any female of reproductive age with abdominal pain or syncope, regardless of reported contraceptive use.
A quantitative hCG level below the discriminatory zone with an empty uterus on ultrasound is highly suspicious for an ectopic pregnancy.
Hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia) in the setting of a suspected ectopic pregnancy suggests rupture and is a surgical emergency.
Free fluid in the Morison's pouch on a FAST exam in this context is likely hemoperitoneum.
Immediate OB/GYN consultation is critical for definitive surgical management.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of sharp lower abdominal pain and dizziness.
initialPresentation.summary: A 26-year-old female presents with acute left lower quadrant pain, syncope, and signs of hemorrhagic shock, with a positive pregnancy test concerning for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports the sudden onset of severe, sharp left lower quadrant pain approximately 2 hours ago. The pain was followed by an episode of syncope. She now feels very dizzy and lightheaded. She has had some light vaginal spotting for the past day. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She uses oral contraceptives but admits to missing several pills last month.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: History of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) 2 years ago.

initial.description: Patient is pale, diaphoretic, and appears anxious. She is lying on the gurney and guarding her lower abdomen.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Distended with diffuse lower abdominal tenderness, maximal in the left lower quadrant. Guarding and rebound tenderness are present.
physicalExamFindings.Pelvic: Cervical motion tenderness is exquisite. Minimal blood in the vaginal vault.

stabilizing.trigger: Establish two large-bore IVs and administer 1L Normal Saline bolus
stabilizing.description: After the initial fluid bolus, the patient's blood pressure has transiently improved, but she remains tachycardic and symptomatic.

improving.description: Post-operatively, the patient is stable in the recovery unit. She is awake, her pain is controlled, and her vital signs have normalized after receiving blood products.

orderableItems.result: Positive.
Positive for free fluid in the pelvis and Morison's pouch.
2,500 mIU/mL.
No intrauterine pregnancy identified. Complex adnexal mass seen in the left adnexa with significant hemoperitoneum.
Patient is A-positive. 2 units of packed red blood cells crossmatched and made available.
OB/GYN team at bedside. Agrees with diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy and recommends immediate transfer to the operating room.
A ruptured left fallopian tube ectopic pregnancy was identified and removed. Approximately 1.5 liters of blood was evacuated from the abdomen.

metadata.title: Hypertensive Emergency
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Hypertensive Emergency with Acute Kidney Injury and Hypertensive Retinopathy
teachingPoints: Hypertensive emergency is defined as severe hypertension (SBP >180 or DBP >120) with evidence of acute end-organ damage.
End-organ damage can manifest as encephalopathy, stroke, AKI, flash pulmonary edema, or aortic dissection.
A fundoscopic exam is critical to look for papilledema, hemorrhages, or exudates (hypertensive retinopathy).
The goal is not to normalize blood pressure, but to lower the mean arterial pressure (MAP) by 10-20% in the first hour and by another 5-15% over the next 23 hours.
IV nicardipine or labetalol infusions are common first-line agents for controlled blood pressure reduction.
Overly rapid reduction in blood pressure can cause ischemic injury to vital organs.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Headache, blurry vision, and a blood pressure of 220/130 mmHg.
initialPresentation.summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents with a severe occipital headache, blurred vision, and chest tightness, consistent with a hypertensive emergency with end-organ damage.

history.presentIllness: The patient presents with a severe, throbbing occipital headache that started abruptly 2 hours ago. He also reports progressive blurry vision in both eyes and a sense of pressure in his chest. He denies focal weakness or speech difficulties. He ran out of his blood pressure medications about a week ago.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years.

initial.description: Patient is alert but anxious and in visible distress due to a severe headache. He is diaphoretic and restless.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Fundoscopic exam reveals bilateral papilledema with hemorrhages and cotton wool spots (Grade IV hypertensive retinopathy).
physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. S4 gallop present.

stabilizing.trigger: Establish IV access and cardiac monitoring
stabilizing.description: IV access has been established and the patient is on a continuous cardiac monitor. He remains symptomatic with severe hypertension.

improving.description: After initiation of the Nicardipine drip, the patient's blood pressure has started to decrease. His headache is subjectively improving and his anxiety is lessening.

orderableItems.result: BUN: 32 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL), indicating acute kidney injury.
Protein: 2+, Blood: 1+, RBC: 5-10/hpf. No casts.
Sinus tachycardia. Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) with strain pattern. No acute ST-segment changes.
Nicardipine drip initiated at 5 mg/hr, titrated to lower Mean Arterial Pressure by 15% over the first hour.
Cardiology consulted. Recommends admission to ICU for continuous blood pressure monitoring and IV antihypertensive titration.

metadata.title: Intussusception
teachingPoints: Intussusception is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children between 6 months and 3 years of age.
The classic triad is intermittent colicky abdominal pain, a sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and currant jelly stool, but not all three are always present.
During painful episodes, infants often draw their knees to their chest and cry inconsolably, followed by periods of lethargy.
Abdominal ultrasound is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice, showing a 'target sign'.
Non-operative reduction with a therapeutic air or contrast enema is the first-line treatment in stable patients.
Surgical intervention is required if enema reduction fails or if there are signs of peritonitis or perforation.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Intermittent screaming spells and vomiting.
initialPresentation.summary: A 9-month-old male presents with paroxysms of severe, colicky abdominal pain, non-bilious vomiting, and lethargy. The physical exam is notable for a palpable abdominal mass, concerning for intussusception.

history.presentIllness: For the past 12 hours, Sammy has had sudden episodes of intense crying and screaming where he pulls his legs up to his chest. These episodes last for several minutes and are followed by periods where he is unusually sleepy and difficult to arouse. He has had several episodes of non-bilious vomiting. His mother reports one diaper with bloody, mucus-like stool ('currant jelly') just prior to arrival.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Recent viral gastroenteritis one week ago.
