initial.description: The infant is lethargic but arouses to stimulation. He appears pale.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft and non-distended between painful episodes. A sausage-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant. The right lower quadrant feels empty (Dance's sign).
physicalExamFindings.Rectal: Guaiac-positive stool with blood and mucus.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluid Bolus
stabilizing.description: After receiving IV fluids, the infant's lethargy has improved slightly. He is more alert and interactive between episodes of pain.

improving.description: Following the procedure, the infant is resting comfortably. He has passed a normal brown stool. He is no longer having painful episodes and is tolerating oral fluids.

orderableItems.result: A 'target sign' is identified in the right upper quadrant, measuring 3 cm in diameter, confirming ileocolic intussusception.
Surgeon at bedside. Recommends proceeding with non-operative reduction via air enema under fluoroscopy.
Successful reduction of the intussusception was achieved with controlled air insufflation under fluoroscopic guidance. Reflux of air into the terminal ileum confirms success.
Patient admitted for a 24-hour observation period to monitor for recurrence, which is most common in the first 24-48 hours.

metadata.title: Necrotizing Fasciitis
teachingPoints: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive, life-threatening soft tissue infection involving the fascia and subcutaneous tissue.
A key clinical feature is pain out of proportion to the physical exam findings.
Hard signs include crepitus (subcutaneous gas), bullae, and skin necrosis, but these are often late findings.
The LRINEC score can help risk-stratify patients, but diagnosis is ultimately clinical and confirmed in the operating room.
This is a surgical emergency requiring immediate, wide surgical debridement of all necrotic tissue.
Broad-spectrum antibiotics (covering gram-positives, gram-negatives, and anaerobes) and hemodynamic support are also critical.
Clindamycin is often included to suppress toxin production.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Excruciating pain and swelling in his right leg.
initialPresentation.summary: A 48-year-old male with diabetes presents with rapidly progressing erythema, swelling, and pain out of proportion to exam on his right lower leg, with systemic signs of toxicity, concerning for necrotizing fasciitis.

history.presentIllness: The patient sustained a small cut on his right shin from a branch while gardening two days ago. Yesterday, the area became red and painful. Over the past 12 hours, the redness has spread rapidly up his leg, and the pain has become excruciating (11/10). He developed fever, chills, and feels generally unwell. The skin has started to look dusky and has developed some blisters.

initial.description: Patient is toxic-appearing, diaphoretic, and in severe distress. His right leg is markedly swollen and erythematous.

physicalExamFindings.Right Lower Extremity: Tense, woody edema and erythema extending from the ankle to the knee. Exquisite tenderness to even light palpation. Several large, violaceous bullae are present. Crepitus is palpable over the shin.

stabilizing.trigger: Initiate Sepsis Protocol: IV Fluids and Broad-Spectrum Antibiotics
stabilizing.description: After aggressive fluid resuscitation and initiation of empiric antibiotics (Vancomycin, Piperacillin-Tazobactam, Clindamycin), the patient's blood pressure has improved, but his leg remains unchanged and he is still in severe pain.

improving.description: The patient is in the ICU post-operatively after extensive debridement of his leg. He is intubated and on vasopressors but is hemodynamically stabilizing. He is scheduled for a second-look operation in 24 hours.

orderableItems.result: Significant soft tissue swelling and subcutaneous gas tracking along fascial planes.
6.2 mmol/L (Elevated, indicating tissue hypoperfusion).
General Surgery consulted emergently. Confirms high suspicion for necrotizing fasciitis and books patient for immediate transfer to the operating room for debridement.
Intraoperatively, 'dishwater' pus and necrotic fascia were found, confirming the diagnosis. Extensive debridement of all non-viable tissue was performed.
Vancomycin, Piperacillin-Tazobactam, and Clindamycin started intravenously.

metadata.title: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
teachingPoints: GBS is an acute, immune-mediated polyneuropathy characterized by ascending, symmetric weakness and areflexia.
It is often preceded by a viral or bacterial infection (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, CMV) 1-3 weeks prior.
A critical and life-threatening complication is respiratory failure due to paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.
Monitor respiratory function closely with serial measurements of negative inspiratory force (NIF) and vital capacity (VC).
Lumbar puncture typically shows albuminocytologic dissociation (high protein with a normal white blood cell count).
Treatment is with Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasmapheresis; steroids are not effective.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Tingling in feet and progressive leg weakness.
initialPresentation.summary: A 32-year-old female presents with a 3-day history of ascending, symmetric lower extremity weakness and loss of reflexes following a recent diarrheal illness, consistent with Guillain-Barré Syndrome.

history.presentIllness: The patient first noticed tingling in her toes three days ago. This progressed to weakness in her feet, and she has had increasing difficulty walking, now requiring assistance to stand. The weakness has been ascending and is now present in her thighs. She denies any sensory level, bowel or bladder incontinence. She had a significant diarrheal illness about two weeks ago that resolved on its own.

initial.description: Patient is sitting in a wheelchair, unable to stand without assistance. She appears anxious about her weakness.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Alert and oriented. Cranial nerves intact. Motor: Symmetric weakness, 4/5 in hip flexion, 3/5 in knee extension, 2/5 in dorsiflexion. Upper extremity strength is 5/5. Reflexes: Absent patellar and Achilles reflexes bilaterally, 2+ in upper extremities.

stabilizing.trigger: Measure Negative Inspiratory Force (NIF) and Vital Capacity (VC)
stabilizing.description: Initial respiratory measurements are within normal limits, but the patient reports a subjective sense of 'shallow breathing.' The weakness has now progressed to involve her hands.

improving.description: After completing a 5-day course of IVIG, the progression of weakness has halted. The patient's respiratory parameters are stable, and she is beginning to show very slight improvement in lower extremity strength.

orderableItems.result: CSF shows: WBC 2 cells/mm³, Protein 150 mg/dL (high), Glucose 65 mg/dL. This albuminocytologic dissociation is classic for GBS.

orderableItems.testName: Measure Negative Inspiratory Force (NIF) and Vital Capacity (VC)
orderableItems.result: Initial NIF is -40 cmH2O and VC is 30 mL/kg. These will be monitored every 4 hours for signs of impending respiratory failure.
A 5-day course of IVIG at 0.4 g/kg/day is started.
Neurology confirms the diagnosis of GBS and recommends admission to the ICU for close respiratory monitoring and initiation of IVIG.
Consult placed for early intervention to maintain range of motion and plan for long-term rehabilitation.

metadata.title: Opioid Overdose
teachingPoints: Opioid overdose is a medical emergency characterized by a classic triad of respiratory depression, altered mental status, and miosis (pinpoint pupils).
The immediate priority is to support breathing (bag-valve mask) and administer an opioid antagonist, naloxone.
Naloxone can be administered IV, IM, or intranasally and can precipitate an acute withdrawal syndrome.
The duration of action of naloxone is often shorter than that of the opioid, requiring close monitoring for recurrent respiratory depression.
After stabilization, it is crucial to address the underlying substance use disorder, offer resources for treatment, and provide harm reduction education (e.g., naloxone kit).
The COWS (Clinical Opiate Withdrawal Scale) can be used to objectively measure withdrawal severity.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Unresponsive.
initialPresentation.summary: A 28-year-old male with a known history of opioid use disorder is brought in by paramedics after being found unresponsive, with pinpoint pupils and severe respiratory depression, consistent with an opioid overdose.

history.presentIllness: The patient was found unresponsive on a park bench by a bystander who called 911. Paramedics noted pinpoint pupils, a respiratory rate of 4 breaths/min, and track marks on his arms. An empty baggie with white powder residue was found nearby. He was given 2 mg of intranasal naloxone by EMS with minimal response.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Unemployed, history of intravenous drug use.

initial.description: Patient is unconscious and cyanotic, with shallow, gasping respirations. He is unresponsive to painful stimuli.

physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Shallow respirations with poor air movement.
physicalExamFindings.Skin: Cool, clammy, with visible track marks on bilateral antecubital fossae.

stabilizing.trigger: Support ventilation with Bag-Valve Mask and Administer IV Naloxone 0.4 mg
stabilizing.description: After initial IV naloxone, the patient's respiratory rate increases to 10 breaths/min and his oxygen saturation improves. He remains unconscious.

improving.description: After a larger dose of naloxone, the patient awakens abruptly. He is agitated, diaphoretic, and complaining of diffuse body aches, consistent with precipitated withdrawal.

orderableItems.result: Patient's respiratory drive and level of consciousness improve after repeated doses.
Positive for opiates and fentanyl.
95 mg/dL.

orderableItems.testName: Social Work / Substance Use Navigator Consult
orderableItems.result: Consult placed to provide counseling, resources for treatment programs, and a take-home naloxone kit upon discharge.
Once awake, patient scores a 15 on the COWS scale (moderate withdrawal). Symptomatic treatment with clonidine and ondansetron is initiated.

metadata.title: Spontaneous Pneumothorax
teachingPoints: Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP) occurs without a precipitating event in a patient with no known lung disease.
It is most common in tall, thin males between the ages of 10 and 30, and is associated with smoking.
Patients typically present with acute onset of unilateral, pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea.
Physical exam findings include decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus on the affected side.
Diagnosis is confirmed with a chest X-ray showing a visceral pleural line and absence of lung markings peripherally.
Management depends on size and symptoms: small, stable PSPs can be observed, while larger or symptomatic ones may require needle aspiration or chest tube placement.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of sharp left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath.
initialPresentation.summary: A 22-year-old tall, thin male who is a smoker presents with acute pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea, with physical exam and imaging findings confirming a primary spontaneous pneumothorax.

history.presentIllness: The patient was sitting at his desk 4 hours ago when he experienced a sudden, sharp, stabbing pain in his left chest. The pain is worse with deep breaths. He has also felt progressively short of breath since the onset. He denies any trauma, fever, or cough.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: College student, smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day. Tall and thin body habitus.

initial.description: Patient is sitting upright on the gurney, appearing anxious and moderately short of breath. He is splinting his left chest.

physicalExamFindings.General: Tall, thin male in mild respiratory distress.
physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion over the entire left lung field. Trachea is midline.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer Supplemental Oxygen
stabilizing.description: After being placed on 2L of oxygen via nasal cannula, the patient's oxygen saturation improves and he reports a slight decrease in his shortness of breath.

improving.description: Following placement of a small-bore chest tube, there is a rush of air and the patient reports immediate and significant relief of his chest pain and dyspnea. The left lung has re-expanded on follow-up X-ray.

orderableItems.result: Large left-sided pneumothorax (estimated 40%) with complete collapse of the left upper lobe. No tension physiology.
A 14-French pigtail catheter was placed in the left pleural space under ultrasound guidance and connected to a water seal device.
Pulmonology consulted. Agrees with management and recommends admission for monitoring of the chest tube.
Oxygen at 2L/min via nasal cannula initiated. This also helps increase the pressure gradient to promote nitrogen resorption from the pleural space.

metadata.title: Infective Endocarditis
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Infective Endocarditis of the Tricuspid Valve secondary to IV Drug Use
teachingPoints: Infective endocarditis (IE) should be suspected in any patient with a fever and a new heart murmur, especially with risk factors like IV drug use or prosthetic valves.
IV drug use is strongly associated with right-sided (tricuspid valve) endocarditis, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
The Duke criteria are used to make a definitive diagnosis, combining clinical, microbiological (blood cultures), and echocardiographic findings.
Peripheral stigmata of IE include Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, splinter hemorrhages, and Roth spots.
Right-sided IE can present with septic pulmonary emboli, causing cough, pleuritic chest pain, and nodular infiltrates on chest imaging.
Treatment requires prolonged courses of high-dose intravenous antibiotics, and surgery may be indicated for complications.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Fever, chills, and shortness of breath for one week.
initialPresentation.summary: A 29-year-old female with a history of intravenous drug use presents with a week of fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain, found to have a new heart murmur and septic pulmonary emboli, consistent with tricuspid valve endocarditis.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports a one-week history of daily fevers, shaking chills, and night sweats. Over the past few days, she has developed a cough and sharp right-sided chest pain that is worse with inspiration. She feels generally weak and has lost her appetite.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Opioid Use Disorder with intravenous use

initial.description: Patient is ill-appearing, febrile, and tachycardic. She appears tired and has poor dentition.

physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border, which increases with inspiration (Carvallo's sign).
physicalExamFindings.Skin: Multiple track marks on bilateral arms. Splinter hemorrhages are noted under several fingernails.

stabilizing.trigger: Obtain Blood Cultures and Administer Empiric IV Vancomycin
stabilizing.description: After blood cultures were drawn from three separate sites and empiric antibiotics were started, the patient's fever has slightly decreased. She remains tachycardic and symptomatic.

improving.description: After blood cultures grew Methicillin-Sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA), antibiotics were narrowed to IV Nafcillin. The patient is now afebrile, and her symptoms are slowly improving.

orderableItems.result: Positive in 3/3 bottles for Gram-positive cocci in clusters within 12 hours. Final identification: Methicillin-Sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA).
A large, mobile, 1.5 cm vegetation is seen on the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve with associated severe tricuspid regurgitation.
Multiple bilateral, peripheral, nodular opacities, some with cavitation, consistent with septic pulmonary emboli.
Consultant confirms diagnosis of definite IE by Duke Criteria. Recommends 6 weeks of IV Nafcillin and will follow for complications.
Consulted due to large vegetation size. Recommends initial trial of medical management but will consider surgery if patient develops heart failure or recurrent emboli.

metadata.title: Myxedema Coma
teachingPoints: Myxedema coma is a rare, life-threatening decompensation of severe hypothyroidism, characterized by altered mental status, hypothermia, and bradycardia.
It is often precipitated by a stressor like infection, cold exposure, or medications in a patient with long-standing, untreated hypothyroidism.
Key features include profound lethargy or coma, hypoventilation with hypercapnia, hypotension, and non-pitting edema.
Do not wait for lab confirmation to treat; if suspicion is high, treatment should be initiated immediately.
Management involves IV levothyroxine (T4), supportive care for hypotension and hypothermia (passive rewarming), and stress-dose steroids (due to potential for concurrent adrenal insufficiency).
Look for and treat the precipitating cause.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Unresponsive.
initialPresentation.summary: A 76-year-old female with a remote history of thyroid surgery is brought in from home with profound lethargy, hypothermia, and bradycardia, consistent with myxedema coma.

history.presentIllness: The patient was found unresponsive in her cold apartment by a neighbor. Her family reports she has been increasingly tired, confused, and constipated over the past several months. She had a 'thyroid surgery' many years ago but has not seen a doctor or taken any medication for it in over a decade.

initial.description: Patient is comatose, responding only to deep sternal rub with minimal movement. She is profoundly hypothermic and bradycardic.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Periorbital edema, macroglossia. A well-healed surgical scar on the neck.
physicalExamFindings.Neurological: GCS 5. Pupils are equal and sluggishly reactive. Hyporeflexia with delayed relaxation phase of reflexes.
physicalExamFindings.Skin: Cool, dry, doughy skin. Non-pitting edema of the hands and feet.

stabilizing.trigger: Intubation and Mechanical Ventilation
stabilizing.description: The patient was intubated for airway protection and hypercapnic respiratory failure. She is being passively rewarmed with blankets.

improving.description: After receiving a loading dose of IV levothyroxine and stress-dose steroids, the patient's heart rate and blood pressure are slowly improving. She is beginning to have some spontaneous movements.

orderableItems.result: TSH: 150 mIU/L (very high). Free T4: <0.1 ng/dL (very low).
pH 7.20, pCO2 75 mmHg, pO2 60 mmHg. Severe respiratory acidosis.
Loading dose of 300 mcg levothyroxine administered intravenously.
100 mg of hydrocortisone administered IV prior to levothyroxine.
Endocrinology consulted emergently. Guides IV thyroid hormone replacement and steroid management. Recommends admission to ICU.

metadata.title: Elderly Hip Fracture
teachingPoints: Hip fractures in the elderly are most commonly caused by low-energy falls and are associated with significant morbidity and mortality.
The classic presentation is an elderly patient with a fall who is unable to bear weight and has a shortened, externally rotated leg.
Initial management includes pain control, immobilization, and a thorough medical evaluation to identify comorbidities that may impact surgical risk.
Co-management with internal medicine or geriatrics is crucial for optimizing the patient for surgery and managing post-operative medical issues.
Surgical treatment (e.g., hemiarthroplasty, total hip arthroplasty, or internal fixation) is typically performed within 24-48 hours to improve outcomes.
Early mobilization with physiotherapy is key to preventing complications like DVT, pneumonia, and deconditioning.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Right hip pain after a fall.
initialPresentation.summary: An 84-year-old female with a history of osteoporosis presents with a painful, shortened, and externally rotated right leg after a ground-level fall, consistent with a hip fracture.

history.presentIllness: The patient tripped on a rug in her home and fell directly onto her right side. She experienced immediate, severe pain in her right hip and groin and has been unable to get up or bear any weight on her right leg since the fall.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Lives alone, uses a cane for ambulation.

initial.description: Patient is lying on the gurney in significant pain, grimacing with any movement of her right leg.

physicalExamFindings.Right Lower Extremity: Shortened and externally rotated. Significant tenderness to palpation over the right hip. Distal pulses and sensation are intact.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Morphine and Obtain X-rays
stabilizing.description: After receiving pain medication, the patient is more comfortable. Imaging has confirmed the diagnosis.

improving.description: The patient is post-operative day 1. Her pain is well-controlled, and she has been evaluated by physiotherapy to begin early mobilization.

orderableItems.testName: X-ray of Right Hip and Pelvis
orderableItems.result: Displaced subcapital fracture of the right femoral neck.
3.2 (Supratherapeutic).
Orthopedics confirms diagnosis and recommends surgical fixation with hemiarthroplasty once INR is corrected.
Medicine co-management consulted for pre-operative optimization, including reversal of anticoagulation with Vitamin K and FFP, and post-operative medical care.
Vitamin K and Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) administered. Repeat INR is 1.4, and patient is cleared for surgery.
Consult placed for post-operative day 1 evaluation and mobilization as tolerated.

metadata.title: Upper GI Bleed
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Upper GI Bleed secondary to a Duodenal Ulcer
teachingPoints: Upper GI Bleed (UGIB) can present with hematemesis (bright red blood or 'coffee grounds'), melena (black, tarry stools), or hematochezia in massive bleeds.
Initial management focuses on hemodynamic resuscitation with IV fluids and blood products, aiming for a hemoglobin >7 g/dL in most patients.
A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion should be started early to stabilize clots.
Risk stratification scores (e.g., Glasgow-Blatchford) can help determine the need for urgent intervention.
Upper endoscopy (EGD) is both diagnostic and therapeutic, allowing for identification of the bleeding source and hemostatic intervention.
Common causes include peptic ulcer disease, esophageal varices, and Mallory-Weiss tears.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Vomiting blood and black stools.
initialPresentation.summary: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic NSAID use presents with hematemesis, melena, and signs of hypovolemia, consistent with an acute upper GI bleed.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports two days of black, tarry stools (melena). This morning, he had two episodes of vomiting large amounts of dark material that looked like 'coffee grounds' (hematemesis). He feels very weak and dizzy, especially upon standing. He takes ibuprofen daily for arthritis.

pastMedicalHistory.medications: Ibuprofen 600mg three times daily, Omeprazole (intermittent compliance)
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Drinks 2-3 beers daily, smokes 1 pack per day.

initial.description: Patient is pale and diaphoretic. He is alert but appears anxious and weak.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, with mild epigastric tenderness. No guarding or rebound.
physicalExamFindings.Rectal: Grossly melenic stool on the examining finger.

stabilizing.trigger: Establish two large-bore IVs, start IV Fluids and IV Pantoprazole
stabilizing.description: After fluid resuscitation and starting a PPI drip, the patient's blood pressure has improved. He remains tachycardic and his hemoglobin is low.

improving.trigger: Transfuse Packed Red Blood Cells and perform EGD
improving.description: Following blood transfusion and successful endoscopic therapy to clip a bleeding ulcer, the patient is hemodynamically stable with no further signs of active bleeding.

orderableItems.result: Hemoglobin: 6.8 g/dL (critically low).
An 80mg IV bolus followed by an 8mg/hr infusion is started.
Two units of pRBCs are transfused. Post-transfusion hemoglobin is 8.5 g/dL.
GI consulted. Recommends urgent EGD for diagnosis and therapy.
A large, 2 cm duodenal ulcer with an actively bleeding visible vessel was identified. Successful hemostasis was achieved with endoscopic clips and epinephrine injection.

metadata.title: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
teachingPoints: PID is an infection of the upper female genital tract, including the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.
It is most often caused by sexually transmitted pathogens like Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.
Clinical diagnosis is based on the presence of lower abdominal or pelvic pain plus one or more of the following on pelvic exam: cervical motion tenderness, uterine tenderness, or adnexal tenderness.
A major long-term complication of PID is tubal factor infertility and an increased risk of ectopic pregnancy.
Outpatient treatment is appropriate for mild-to-moderate PID and typically involves a single IM dose of ceftriaxone plus a 14-day course of oral doxycycline.
Indications for inpatient admission include severe illness, inability to tolerate oral medications, or tubo-ovarian abscess.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Worsening lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge.
initialPresentation.summary: A 24-year-old sexually active female presents with a 4-day history of bilateral lower abdominal pain, purulent vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness on exam, consistent with Pelvic Inflammatory Disease.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports a 4-day history of dull, aching, bilateral lower abdominal pain. The pain has been gradually worsening. She has also noted a new, yellow, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She experienced some spotting after intercourse two days ago. She denies fever or vomiting. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Sexually active with a new male partner in the last month, does not consistently use condoms.

initial.description: Patient is uncomfortable but in no acute distress. She is afebrile.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, with moderate tenderness to deep palpation in both lower quadrants. No guarding or rebound.
physicalExamFindings.Pelvic: Purulent discharge is noted at the cervical os. Speculum exam is otherwise normal. Bimanual exam reveals significant cervical motion tenderness ('chandelier sign') and bilateral adnexal tenderness.

stabilizing.trigger: Obtain swabs for Gonorrhea/Chlamydia testing
stabilizing.description: Specimens have been collected for STI testing. The patient is awaiting initial treatment.

improving.trigger: Administer Ceftriaxone IM and prescribe Doxycycline
improving.description: The patient has received her IM antibiotic and has the prescription for the oral course. She has been educated on the importance of completing the full course, abstaining from intercourse, and having her partner treated.

orderableItems.result: Negative.

orderableItems.testName: Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) for Gonorrhea/Chlamydia
orderableItems.result: Pending. (Later returns positive for Chlamydia trachomatis).
Single dose of ceftriaxone administered in the clinic.

orderableItems.testName: Prescribe Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 14 days
orderableItems.result: Prescription provided to the patient with counseling.
Numerous white blood cells seen on microscopy. No trichomonads or clue cells.

metadata.title: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
teachingPoints: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a colorless, odorless gas produced by incomplete combustion; suspect exposure in patients with flu-like symptoms in winter, especially with faulty heating systems.
Presentation can be vague: headache, dizziness, nausea. Multiple family members with similar symptoms is a major red flag.
Pulse oximetry is unreliable as it cannot differentiate carboxyhemoglobin from oxyhemoglobin.
Diagnosis is made by measuring a carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) level on a blood gas analysis.
Treatment is 100% high-flow oxygen. Hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy is indicated for severe cases (e.g., syncope, coma, COHb >25%, or pregnancy).

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Severe headache and dizziness.
initialPresentation.summary: A 45-year-old male presents in mid-winter with a severe headache, dizziness, and nausea. His wife, who is with him, reports similar but milder symptoms, raising suspicion for a toxic exposure.

history.presentIllness: The patient developed a severe, throbbing headache and dizziness over the past 6 hours. He feels profoundly weak and nauseous. He denies fever or other infectious symptoms. His wife, who accompanied him, also feels unwell with a headache. They live in an old house and have been using a gas furnace for heating. He denies any intentional overdose or substance use.

initial.description: Patient is alert and oriented but appears fatigued and complains of a severe headache. His skin is flushed.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Alert and oriented x4. Normal strength, sensation, and reflexes. Mild ataxia on gait testing.

stabilizing.trigger: Place on 100% Oxygen via Non-Rebreather Mask
stabilizing.description: After initiating high-flow oxygen, the patient reports his headache is slightly improving. He remains tachycardic.

improving.description: Following a session of hyperbaric oxygen therapy, the patient's headache and dizziness have completely resolved. His carboxyhemoglobin level has returned to a normal range.

orderableItems.result: 30% (Critically elevated).
Sinus tachycardia. No ischemic changes.

orderableItems.testName: Place on 100% Oxygen via Non-Rebreather Mask
orderableItems.result: Patient placed on 15L/min non-rebreather mask to facilitate washout of carbon monoxide.
Toxicology consulted. Due to the high COHb level, transfer to a facility with a hyperbaric chamber is recommended and arranged.
2.5 mmol/L (Mildly elevated due to tissue hypoxia).

metadata.title: Pericardial Tamponade
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Malignant Pericardial Effusion causing Cardiac Tamponade
teachingPoints: Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition caused by the accumulation of pericardial fluid, leading to impaired ventricular filling and cardiogenic shock.
Beck's triad (hypotension, jugular venous distention, muffled heart sounds) is classic but not always present.
Pulsus paradoxus (an exaggerated drop in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration) is a key physical exam finding.
Echocardiography is the diagnostic modality of choice, showing a large effusion, right ventricular diastolic collapse, and a swinging heart.
This is a true medical emergency requiring immediate pericardiocentesis to relieve the pressure.
Electrical alternans on EKG is a specific but insensitive finding.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Progressive shortness of breath and chest pressure.
initialPresentation.summary: A 52-year-old female with a history of lung cancer presents with progressive dyspnea, hypotension, and jugular venous distention, with exam and imaging findings consistent with cardiac tamponade.

history.presentIllness: The patient has had worsening shortness of breath for the past week, now occurring even at rest. She feels a constant pressure in her chest and feels extremely fatigued and lightheaded, especially when sitting up. She denies sharp pain or fever.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Stage III Adenocarcinoma of the Lung, diagnosed 6 months ago, currently undergoing chemotherapy.

initial.description: Patient is sitting upright, appearing anxious and in significant respiratory distress. She is pale and cool to the touch.

physicalExamFindings.General: In extremis, using accessory muscles to breathe.
physicalExamFindings.Neck: Jugular venous distention is present up to the angle of the jaw.
physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, with distant, muffled heart sounds. A pulsus paradoxus of 20 mmHg is measured.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluid Bolus
stabilizing.description: A 500cc fluid bolus is given to transiently increase preload and right-sided filling pressures, leading to a slight improvement in blood pressure while preparing for definitive intervention.

improving.description: After removal of 500 mL of serosanguinous fluid from the pericardial space, the patient experiences immediate and dramatic improvement. Her blood pressure normalizes, heart rate decreases, and she is no longer short of breath.

orderableItems.result: Large, circumferential pericardial effusion with evidence of right ventricular diastolic collapse and a plethoric IVC. Confirms cardiac tamponade physiology.
Sinus tachycardia, low voltage QRS complexes, and electrical alternans.
Cardiology emergently consulted. Confirms tamponade at the bedside with ultrasound and prepares for immediate pericardiocentesis.
500 mL of serosanguinous fluid was drained. A pericardial drain was left in place. Fluid sent for cytology.
Enlarged, 'water bottle' shaped cardiac silhouette.

metadata.title: New Onset Type 1 Diabetes
metadata.finalDiagnosis: New Onset Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus presenting in Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
teachingPoints: New onset Type 1 Diabetes often presents with the classic triad of polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia, frequently accompanied by weight loss.
A significant percentage of children present for the first time in DKA, which can be precipitated by a minor illness.
DKA in children is characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and acidosis, and requires careful management of fluids, insulin, and electrolytes.
Cerebral edema is a rare but devastating complication of DKA treatment in children; avoid overly rapid correction of glucose and osmolarity.
Management requires a multidisciplinary team including pediatric endocrinology and diabetes educators.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Vomiting, abdominal pain, and increased urination for 2 days.
initialPresentation.summary: An 8-year-old male presents with a several-week history of polydipsia and weight loss, now with acute vomiting, abdominal pain, and lethargy, found to be in moderate DKA as his initial presentation of Type 1 Diabetes.

history.presentIllness: For the past 2 days, Andy has had multiple episodes of vomiting and complaining of belly pain. He has been very tired and breathing rapidly. His parents also note that for the past month he has been drinking fluids constantly, urinating frequently (including wetting the bed at night), and has lost about 10 pounds despite having a good appetite.

initial.description: The child is lethargic, with dry mucous membranes. He is breathing deeply and rapidly (Kussmaul respirations) and has a fruity odor on his breath.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Dry mucous membranes, sunken eyes. Fruity odor on breath.
physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Deep, rapid (Kussmaul) respirations. Lungs are clear.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluid Bolus (10 mL/kg Normal Saline)
stabilizing.description: After a careful fluid bolus, the patient's heart rate has decreased slightly. He remains lethargic and tachypneic.

improving.description: Several hours into the insulin drip and maintenance fluids, the patient is more alert and his respiratory rate is decreasing. His acidosis is beginning to correct.

orderableItems.result: 480 mg/dL.
VBG: pH 7.18, pCO2 25, HCO3 10. Serum Beta-Hydroxybutyrate: 6.5 mmol/L (high).
Large glucose, large ketones.
After initial fluid resuscitation, a regular insulin infusion is started at 0.1 units/kg/hr.
Endocrinology consulted. Guides DKA management protocol with close monitoring of neurologic status and electrolytes. Will arrange for diabetes education for the family.

metadata.title: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia secondary to Embolus from Atrial Fibrillation
teachingPoints: Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI) is a surgical emergency with a very high mortality rate.
The hallmark clinical feature is severe, diffuse abdominal pain that is strikingly out of proportion to the findings on physical examination.
The most common cause is an embolus to the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), often in a patient with atrial fibrillation.
Markedly elevated lactate and metabolic acidosis are key laboratory findings, indicating bowel infarction.
CT Angiography of the abdomen and pelvis is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice.
Immediate surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy with embolectomy and possible bowel resection) is required to restore blood flow and resect non-viable bowel.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of severe, diffuse abdominal pain.
initialPresentation.summary: A 72-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with the sudden onset of excruciating abdominal pain, but his abdominal exam is deceptively benign, raising high suspicion for acute mesenteric ischemia.

history.presentIllness: The patient was in his usual state of health until 3 hours ago, when he experienced the sudden onset of severe, diffuse, constant abdominal pain, which he rates as 10/10. He has had one episode of forceful vomiting and a small, loose bowel movement. The pain is not relieved by any position.

initial.description: Patient is writhing in pain on the gurney, appearing pale and diaphoretic.

physicalExamFindings.General: In severe distress due to pain.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, non-distended. Mild, diffuse tenderness to deep palpation, but no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. (Pain is strikingly out of proportion to exam).

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluids and obtain urgent labs
stabilizing.description: The patient has received IV fluids. His labs return showing a profound metabolic acidosis.

improving.description: The patient is now in the surgical ICU post-operatively after an SMA embolectomy and resection of a segment of necrotic small bowel. He is on vasopressors and being managed for septic shock.

orderableItems.result: 12.5 mmol/L (Critically elevated).
pH 7.15, HCO3 12. Severe metabolic acidosis.
Filling defect consistent with an embolus is seen in the proximal superior mesenteric artery (SMA) with poor distal vessel opacification and evidence of small bowel ischemia.
Vascular and General Surgery consulted emergently. Patient taken directly to the operating room from the CT scanner for exploratory laparotomy.
An embolus was removed from the SMA. A large segment of the jejunum was found to be necrotic and was resected. A second-look laparotomy is planned.

metadata.title: Myasthenic Crisis
teachingPoints: Myasthenic crisis is a life-threatening complication of myasthenia gravis, characterized by worsening muscle weakness leading to respiratory failure.
It is often triggered by infection, surgery, or certain medications.
Patients present with rapidly progressive weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and respiratory distress (inability to handle secretions, shallow breathing).
Closely monitor respiratory function with serial NIF and VC measurements; a NIF worse than -30 cmH2O or VC <20 mL/kg are indications for elective intubation.
Treatment involves immunomodulatory therapy (IVIG or plasmapheresis) and supportive care, including mechanical ventilation.
Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., pyridostigmine) are typically held during a crisis to reduce airway secretions.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Worsening weakness and difficulty breathing.
initialPresentation.summary: A 35-year-old female with a known history of myasthenia gravis presents with rapidly progressive generalized weakness and acute respiratory distress after a recent upper respiratory infection, consistent with a myasthenic crisis.

history.presentIllness: The patient has had myasthenia gravis for 5 years. She developed a cold 3 days ago. Over the past 24 hours, she has experienced profound worsening of her usual weakness. She now has difficulty holding her head up, chewing, and swallowing her saliva. Over the last few hours, she has become extremely short of breath.

initial.description: Patient is sitting upright in bed, appearing anxious and in obvious respiratory distress. She is using accessory muscles and has a weak, nasal-sounding voice.

physicalExamFindings.General: In respiratory distress, unable to handle secretions.
physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Alert and oriented. Bilateral ptosis and diplopia. Significant facial weakness. Dysarthria. Neck flexion is 2/5. Proximal arm and leg strength is 3/5.

stabilizing.trigger: Measure NIF and VC; Elective Intubation
stabilizing.description: Respiratory parameters show impending failure. The patient is electively intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation, which relieves her work of breathing.

improving.description: After three sessions of plasmapheresis, the patient's muscle strength is beginning to improve. She is participating with physical therapy and is being assessed for ventilator weaning.

orderableItems.testName: Measure Negative Inspiratory Force (NIF) and Vital Capacity (VC)
orderableItems.result: NIF is -15 cmH2O (critically low). VC is 10 mL/kg (critically low).
Patient successfully intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation for airway protection and respiratory support.
A central line is placed and the patient begins a 5-day course of plasma exchange.
Neurology confirms myasthenic crisis. Recommends holding pyridostigmine, starting plasmapheresis, and admission to the Neuro-ICU.
Right lower lobe infiltrate, suggesting an underlying pneumonia as the trigger for the crisis.

metadata.title: Anorexia Nervosa & Refeeding
teachingPoints: Anorexia nervosa is a psychiatric disorder with severe medical complications due to malnutrition.
Indications for medical admission include hemodynamic instability (bradycardia, hypotension), electrolyte abnormalities, and very low body weight (e.g., <75% ideal body weight).
Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal shift in fluids and electrolytes that can occur in malnourished patients receiving artificial refeeding.
The hallmark is hypophosphatemia, but hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia also occur, leading to cardiac and respiratory failure.
To prevent it, start nutritional rehabilitation slowly ('start low, go slow') and aggressively monitor and replete electrolytes, especially phosphate.
A multidisciplinary team including medicine, psychiatry, and nutrition is essential for safe management.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Dizziness and fainting.
initialPresentation.summary: A 19-year-old female with a history of severe weight loss is admitted for medical stabilization of anorexia nervosa. Upon initiation of feeding, she develops profound hypophosphatemia and weakness, consistent with refeeding syndrome.

history.presentIllness: The patient is admitted to the medical unit for severe malnutrition due to her anorexia nervosa. Her BMI is 14.5. She has had several episodes of fainting. On hospital day 2, after a nasogastric feeding tube was placed and feeds were initiated, she complains of profound weakness, shortness of breath, and has new lower extremity edema.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: College student, lives in a dorm.

initial.description: Patient is emaciated, with lanugo and dry skin. She is bradycardic and hypotensive.

physicalExamFindings.Skin: Dry, with fine, downy hair (lanugo) on her back and arms.

stabilizing.trigger: Initiate Enteral Nutrition via NG Tube
stabilizing.description: A nasogastric tube is placed and continuous feeds are started at a low rate (10 kcal/kg/day).

improving.trigger: Administer IV Phosphate and decrease feeds
improving.description: After aggressive electrolyte repletion and a reduction in caloric intake, the patient's phosphate levels are improving. Her weakness and edema are resolving. Nutritional rehabilitation will be advanced more slowly.

orderableItems.result: Potassium 3.4, Magnesium 1.6, Phosphate 2.5. All low-normal.
Potassium 2.8, Magnesium 1.2, Phosphate 0.9 (critically low).
Aggressive IV phosphate repletion initiated per protocol.
Psychiatry team is co-managing the patient, providing behavioral support and planning for transfer to a specialized eating disorder unit once medically stable.
Dietitian is closely involved in calculating caloric needs, recommending a slow advancement of feeds, and monitoring for refeeding syndrome.

metadata.title: Ovarian Torsion
teachingPoints: Ovarian torsion is a gynecologic emergency caused by the twisting of the ovary around its own ligamentous supports, cutting off its blood supply.
It typically presents with the sudden onset of severe, unilateral pelvic pain, often associated with nausea and vomiting.
Risk factors include an ovarian cyst or mass, which acts as a lead point for the torsion.
Pelvic ultrasound with Doppler is the primary imaging modality. Findings include an enlarged, edematous ovary with decreased or absent blood flow.
The 'whirlpool sign' on ultrasound, representing the twisted vascular pedicle, is a specific finding.
Definitive diagnosis and treatment require emergent surgery (laparoscopy) to de-tort the ovary and preserve its function.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of severe right-sided pelvic pain.
initialPresentation.summary: A 25-year-old female presents with acute, severe, right-sided pelvic pain and vomiting, with ultrasound findings consistent with ovarian torsion.

history.presentIllness: The patient was watching TV 3 hours ago when she experienced a sudden onset of severe, constant, right-sided pelvic pain. The pain is sharp, rated 9/10, and does not radiate. She has had two episodes of non-bilious vomiting associated with the pain. She denies fever, vaginal discharge, or urinary symptoms. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: History of a right ovarian cyst noted on a previous ultrasound.
pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Sexually active, uses condoms for contraception.

initial.description: Patient is lying on her side on the gurney, crying and guarding her right lower abdomen.

physicalExamFindings.General: In severe distress due to pain.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, with marked tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant. Voluntary guarding present.
physicalExamFindings.Pelvic: Bimanual exam reveals a tender, enlarged right adnexa. Significant right adnexal tenderness.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Morphine and Ondansetron
stabilizing.description: After receiving IV pain and anti-nausea medication, the patient is more comfortable but still has significant focal tenderness.

improving.description: The patient is in the recovery room post-operatively. The surgeon was able to de-tort the right ovary, which appeared viable. Her pain is now well-controlled.

orderableItems.result: Negative.

The right ovary is enlarged (8 cm) and edematous with peripherally displaced follicles. No arterial or venous flow is detected on Doppler interrogation. A large simple cyst is noted. These findings are highly consistent with ovarian torsion.
GYN service consulted emergently. Recommends immediate transfer to the operating room for diagnostic laparoscopy with likely detorsion.
The right ovary was found to be torsed three times on its pedicle and was dusky. It was successfully de-torted, and color returned to the ovary, indicating viability. The associated cyst was drained.

metadata.title: Septic Arthritis
teachingPoints: Septic arthritis is a direct infection of a joint space and is an orthopedic emergency that can rapidly destroy cartilage.
Patients present with an acute onset of a single, hot, swollen, erythematous, and exquisitely painful joint, with severely limited range of motion.
The knee is the most commonly affected joint in adults.
Definitive diagnosis is made by arthrocentesis (joint aspiration). Synovial fluid will show a high WBC count (typically >50,000/mm³ with a neutrophil predominance), positive gram stain, and culture.
Management requires emergent surgical irrigation and debridement of the joint, followed by a prolonged course of intravenous antibiotics.
Always consider disseminated gonococcal infection in a young, sexually active patient with septic arthritis.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Severe right knee pain and swelling.
initialPresentation.summary: A 30-year-old male presents with an acute onset of a hot, swollen, and exquisitely tender right knee, with fever and an inability to bear weight, consistent with septic arthritis.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports a 2-day history of worsening right knee pain and swelling. Today, he was unable to put any weight on the leg due to the pain. The knee is red and feels very warm. He has also had a fever and chills. He denies any recent trauma to the knee.

initial.description: Patient is in a wheelchair, refusing to move his right leg due to severe pain. The knee is visibly swollen and red.

physicalExamFindings.Right Knee: Large effusion, marked erythema, and warmth. Exquisite tenderness to palpation. Range of motion is severely limited due to pain (patient holds it in a flexed position).

stabilizing.trigger: Perform Arthrocentesis
stabilizing.description: A joint aspiration is performed, yielding a large amount of purulent fluid. This relieves some pressure, but the patient remains in significant pain.

improving.description: The patient is post-operative day 1. His fever has resolved, and his knee pain is significantly improved. The knee remains swollen but is less erythematous. He is receiving IV antibiotics.

orderableItems.result: Appearance: Opaque, purulent. WBC: 120,000/mm³ (95% neutrophils). Gram Stain: Gram-positive cocci in clusters. Crystals: None.
Blood cultures are pending. CRP: 250 mg/L (high), ESR: 88 mm/hr (high).
Orthopedics consulted emergently. Based on the purulent aspirate, they recommend immediate surgical irrigation and debridement.
Empiric IV antibiotics started to cover for suspected MRSA.
The knee joint was opened and washed out with several liters of sterile saline. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

metadata.title: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) secondary to Sepsis
teachingPoints: ARDS is a form of acute, diffuse, inflammatory lung injury leading to increased pulmonary vascular permeability and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
It is defined by the Berlin Criteria: acute onset (<1 week), bilateral opacities on imaging not explained by effusions or collapse, and hypoxemia (PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300 mmHg) with PEEP ≥5 cmH2O.
ARDS is always caused by an underlying insult, such as sepsis, pneumonia, pancreatitis, or trauma.
Management is supportive and focuses on treating the underlying cause and lung-protective ventilation.
Lung-protective ventilation involves low tidal volumes (6 mL/kg ideal body weight), maintaining a plateau pressure <30 cmH2O, and using PEEP to improve oxygenation.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Worsening shortness of breath and hypoxia.
initialPresentation.summary: A 45-year-old female admitted 2 days ago for severe pancreatitis now develops rapidly worsening hypoxemic respiratory failure with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, consistent with ARDS.

history.presentIllness: The patient was admitted to the hospital 48 hours ago with severe acute pancreatitis. Despite aggressive fluid resuscitation, she has become progressively more tachypneic and hypoxic, with her oxygen requirement increasing from room air to a non-rebreather mask. She was just transferred to the ICU for impending respiratory failure.

initial.description: Patient is in the ICU, appears anxious and is in severe respiratory distress, using accessory muscles despite being on a 100% non-rebreather mask.

physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Tachypneic, with diffuse crackles throughout both lung fields.

stabilizing.trigger: Intubation and Initiation of Mechanical Ventilation
stabilizing.description: The patient is intubated for severe hypoxemic respiratory failure. She is sedated and paralyzed.

improving.trigger: Implement ARDSNet Protocol (Low Tidal Volume Ventilation)
improving.description: The patient is being ventilated according to the ARDSNet protocol with low tidal volumes and appropriate PEEP. Her oxygenation is slowly improving, and her plateau pressures are within the target range.

orderableItems.result: Diffuse, bilateral, airspace opacities (pulmonary edema). The heart size is normal.
pH 7.30, pCO2 50, PaO2 55 mmHg. Severe hypoxemia.
PaO2 of 55 on 100% FiO2 gives a P/F ratio of 55, indicating severe ARDS.
Normal left ventricular function with no evidence of elevated filling pressures, ruling out a primary cardiogenic cause for the pulmonary edema.
ICU team managing the patient. Confirms diagnosis of severe ARDS and implements lung-protective ventilation strategy.

metadata.title: Malaria
teachingPoints: Malaria must be considered in any patient with a fever who has traveled to an endemic area.
Plasmodium falciparum can cause severe, life-threatening malaria, while other species typically cause uncomplicated illness.
Classic symptoms include cyclical fevers, chills, sweats, headache, and myalgias.
Diagnosis is made by identifying parasites on a Giemsa-stained thick and thin blood smear.
Signs of severe malaria include altered mental status (cerebral malaria), severe anemia, renal failure, ARDS, and high levels of parasitemia (>5%).
Severe falciparum malaria is a medical emergency treated with intravenous artesunate.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: High fever and confusion after a trip to Africa.
initialPresentation.summary: A 38-year-old male presents with high fevers, chills, and confusion one week after returning from a trip to Nigeria, with blood smears confirming a diagnosis of severe falciparum malaria.

history.presentIllness: The patient returned from a 2-week trip to rural Nigeria one week ago. He began feeling unwell 3 days ago with high fevers, shaking chills, and a severe headache. Today, he has become confused and lethargic. He reports he was prescribed malaria prophylaxis but took it inconsistently.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Health enthusiast, travels frequently for charity work.

initial.description: Patient is febrile, diaphoretic, and lethargic. He is disoriented to time and place.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Splenomegaly is noted on palpation.
physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Confused and disoriented (A&O x2). No focal deficits.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluids and obtain blood smears
stabilizing.description: After fluid resuscitation, the patient's blood pressure has improved. He remains febrile and confused while awaiting diagnostic results.

improving.description: Within 24 hours of starting IV artesunate, the patient is more alert and oriented. His fever has started to resolve, and his parasite burden is decreasing.

orderableItems.result: Thick smear: Positive for Plasmodium parasites. Thin smear: Plasmodium falciparum identified, with a parasitemia of 8%.
Hemoglobin 8.5 g/dL (anemia), Platelets 45,000/uL (thrombocytopenia).
Total Bilirubin 4.5 mg/dL (high), Creatinine 1.8 mg/dL (high).
First dose of IV artesunate administered as per protocol for severe malaria.
ID consulted emergently. Confirms diagnosis and guides treatment with IV artesunate. Recommends admission to ICU for monitoring.

metadata.title: Adrenal Crisis
teachingPoints: Adrenal crisis is a life-threatening emergency caused by an acute deficiency of cortisol.

It occurs in patients with known adrenal insufficiency (e.g., Addison's disease) during a physiologic stressor (e.g., infection) without appropriate stress-dose steroid coverage, or as the initial presentation.
Hallmark presentation is refractory shock (hypotension unresponsive to fluids and vasopressors).
Key lab findings include hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia.
Treatment should not be delayed for diagnostic testing. If suspected, immediately administer IV hydrocortisone.
Management also includes aggressive volume resuscitation with dextrose-containing fluids.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Vomiting, weakness, and low blood pressure.
initialPresentation.summary: A 45-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease on chronic steroids presents with refractory hypotension, weakness, and electrolyte abnormalities after developing gastroenteritis, consistent with an adrenal crisis.

history.presentIllness: The patient has been on chronic prednisone for rheumatoid arthritis. She developed a viral gastroenteritis 2 days ago with vomiting and diarrhea and has been unable to take her oral prednisone. Today, she has become profoundly weak, dizzy, and confused. Her husband called EMS when she became difficult to arouse.

initial.description: Patient is lethargic and confused, with signs of severe dehydration.

physicalExamFindings.Skin: No hyperpigmentation noted (as this is secondary adrenal insufficiency from chronic steroid use).

stabilizing.trigger: Administer 2L IV Normal Saline Bolus
stabilizing.description: Despite aggressive fluid resuscitation, the patient remains profoundly hypotensive.

improving.description: Within an hour of receiving stress-dose steroids, the patient's blood pressure has significantly improved, and she is becoming more alert and oriented.

orderableItems.result: Sodium: 125 mEq/L (hyponatremia), Potassium: 5.9 mEq/L (hyperkalemia), Glucose: 55 mg/dL (hypoglycemia).
Patient receives an IV push of 100 mg hydrocortisone, with dramatic improvement in hemodynamics.
Blood drawn prior to steroid administration. Cortisol: 2 mcg/dL (inappropriately low for a critically ill patient).
IV fluids switched to dextrose-containing solution to correct hypoglycemia and provide volume.
Endocrinology consulted. Confirms diagnosis and guides ongoing steroid and fluid management. Emphasizes need for patient education on stress-dosing steroids.

metadata.title: Giant Cell Arteritis
teachingPoints: GCA is a vasculitis of large and medium-sized arteries, typically affecting patients over the age of 50.
Classic symptoms include a new-onset headache (often temporal), jaw claudication, and visual disturbances.
The most feared complication is irreversible vision loss due to arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (A-AION).
GCA is strongly associated with Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR), which causes pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips.
Elevated inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP) are characteristic.
If GCA is clinically suspected, high-dose corticosteroids should be started immediately to prevent blindness, without waiting for diagnostic confirmation.
Temporal artery biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis but should not delay treatment.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: New headache and pain with chewing.
initialPresentation.summary: A 72-year-old male presents with a new-onset temporal headache, jaw claudication, and transient visual loss, with markedly elevated inflammatory markers, consistent with Giant Cell Arteritis.

history.presentIllness: For the past two weeks, the patient has had a new, persistent headache localized to his right temple. He also reports pain in his jaw when he chews food for more than a minute (jaw claudication). This morning, he had an episode where it felt like a 'curtain came down' over his right eye for about 5 minutes, which has since resolved. He has also felt generally unwell with fatigue and low-grade fevers.

initial.description: Patient is well-appearing but uncomfortable due to his headache.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Right temporal artery is tender to palpation, thickened, and has a decreased pulse compared to the left.
physicalExamFindings.Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Fundoscopic exam is normal.

stabilizing.trigger: Obtain urgent inflammatory markers
stabilizing.description: Labs have been drawn and sent stat. The patient is awaiting results and initiation of treatment.

improving.description: After receiving the first dose of high-dose steroids, the patient reports his headache and jaw pain are significantly improved. He has been admitted for continued treatment and to arrange for a temporal artery biopsy.

orderableItems.testName: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) and C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
orderableItems.result: ESR: 110 mm/hr (high). CRP: 95 mg/L (high).
High-dose IV steroids initiated immediately upon high clinical suspicion to prevent vision loss.
Rheumatology consulted. Agrees with diagnosis and management. Recommends admission and arranging for a temporal artery biopsy within the next week.
Ophthalmology consulted emergently. Confirms no signs of active ischemic optic neuropathy at present but agrees with the urgent need for steroids.
Scheduled as an outpatient. (Pathology would later confirm panarteritis with multinucleated giant cells).

metadata.title: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
teachingPoints: SJS is a severe, life-threatening mucocutaneous reaction, most often triggered by medications like allopurinol, lamotrigine, and sulfonamides.
It is characterized by fever and flu-like symptoms followed by the rapid onset of erythematous, dusky red macules, and extensive mucosal involvement.
A positive Nikolsky sign (sloughing of epidermis with light pressure) is a key finding.
SJS is a medical emergency requiring immediate discontinuation of the offending agent and admission to a burn unit or ICU for supportive care.
Management is similar to a severe burn, focusing on fluid/electrolyte balance, wound care, and pain control.
Ophthalmology consultation is critical due to the high risk of permanent ocular damage.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Painful rash and mouth sores.
initialPresentation.summary: A 55-year-old male, who recently started allopurinol for gout, presents with a rapidly progressing, painful, dusky rash, fever, and severe mucosal erosions, consistent with Stevens-Johnson Syndrome.

history.presentIllness: The patient began taking allopurinol three weeks ago. Four days ago, he developed a fever and malaise. Two days ago, a red rash started on his trunk and has since spread, becoming painful and developing blisters. He has also developed extremely painful sores in his mouth and on his lips, making it difficult to eat or drink. His eyes are red and painful.

initial.description: Patient is febrile, ill-appearing, and in significant pain. He has a widespread erythematous rash with some dusky centers and early bullae formation.

physicalExamFindings.Skin: Diffuse erythematous macules with purpuric centers on the trunk and extremities (<10% body surface area). Positive Nikolsky sign. Several flaccid bullae are present.
physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Severe hemorrhagic crusting of the lips, extensive oral erosions. Bilateral conjunctival injection with purulent discharge.

stabilizing.trigger: Discontinue Allopurinol and start IV Fluids
stabilizing.description: The offending agent has been stopped, and aggressive fluid resuscitation has begun. The patient's skin continues to slough, and he requires significant analgesia.

improving.trigger: Transfer to Burn ICU for supportive care
improving.description: In the burn unit, the patient is receiving specialized wound care, nutritional support, and pain management. His hemodynamics are stable, and no new lesions are forming.

orderableItems.result: Full-thickness epidermal necrosis with subepidermal cleavage. Confirms diagnosis of SJS.
Dermatology confirms clinical diagnosis of SJS and recommends immediate transfer to a burn unit for optimal supportive care.
Ophthalmology consulted emergently. Notes severe conjunctivitis with early symblepharon formation. Initiates aggressive lubrication and steroid eye drops.
Offending drug immediately stopped and listed as a severe allergy.

metadata.title: Esophageal Variceal Bleed
teachingPoints: Variceal hemorrhage is a life-threatening complication of portal hypertension in patients with cirrhosis.
Initial management priorities are hemodynamic resuscitation with fluids and blood products (restrictive transfusion goal Hb 7-9 g/dL), and airway protection.
All patients with a variceal bleed should receive vasoactive medication (e.g., octreotide) to reduce splanchnic blood flow, and prophylactic antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone) to prevent SBP.
Emergent upper endoscopy (EGD) is required for diagnosis and therapeutic intervention (band ligation).
A non-selective beta-blocker (e.g., nadolol) should be started for secondary prophylaxis after the acute bleed is controlled.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Vomiting large amounts of bright red blood.
initialPresentation.summary: A 58-year-old male with a known history of alcohol-related cirrhosis presents with massive hematemesis and hemodynamic instability, consistent with an acute esophageal variceal hemorrhage.

history.presentIllness: The patient was at home when he had a sudden, large-volume vomit of bright red blood. He has had two similar episodes since. He feels extremely weak and dizzy. His family called 911. He has not had a bowel movement today.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Decompensated Cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use, ascites, esophageal varices (not on beta-blocker prophylaxis).

initial.description: Patient is pale, diaphoretic, and actively vomiting blood. He is lethargic but arousable.

physicalExamFindings.General: Acutely ill, jaundiced, with signs of shock.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Distended with a positive fluid wave (ascites). Caput medusae present.
physicalExamFindings.Skin: Spider angiomata on the chest. Palmar erythema.

stabilizing.trigger: Resuscitation: 2 large-bore IVs, IV Fluids, start Octreotide and Ceftriaxone
stabilizing.description: After initial fluid resuscitation and initiation of medical therapy, the patient's blood pressure has improved slightly, but he remains tachycardic and continues to have hematemesis.

improving.description: Following successful endoscopic band ligation of several large varices, the active bleeding has stopped. The patient has been transfused and is now hemodynamically stable.

orderableItems.result: Initial Hemoglobin is 6.2 g/dL. Two units of packed red blood cells are transfused.
Octreotide bolus and continuous infusion started to reduce variceal pressure.
Prophylactic antibiotics given to reduce risk of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
GI emergently consulted. Takes patient for immediate EGD.
Three columns of large esophageal varices are identified, with active spurting from one. Successful hemostasis is achieved with endoscopic band ligation.

metadata.title: Tumor Lysis Syndrome
teachingPoints: TLS is an oncologic emergency caused by the massive and rapid death of cancer cells, releasing their intracellular contents into the bloodstream.
It is most common in patients with high-grade hematologic malignancies (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma, ALL) after initiation of chemotherapy.
The hallmark laboratory findings are hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia (due to binding with phosphate), and hyperuricemia.
These electrolyte shifts can lead to life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and acute kidney injury from crystal deposition.
Prophylaxis with aggressive hydration and a uric acid-lowering agent (allopurinol or rasburicase) is key in high-risk patients.
Treatment of established TLS involves aggressive hydration, rasburicase, and management of electrolyte abnormalities, often requiring ICU care.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Nausea and muscle cramps after first chemotherapy treatment.
initialPresentation.summary: A 45-year-old male who just started chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma develops acute kidney injury and severe electrolyte abnormalities, consistent with acute Tumor Lysis Syndrome.

history.presentIllness: The patient was diagnosed with high-grade Burkitt lymphoma and received his first cycle of chemotherapy 24 hours ago. This morning, he began feeling nauseous and developed muscle cramps and tingling in his hands. The nursing staff noted he has had decreased urine output and a STAT lab panel was drawn.

initial.description: Patient is alert but anxious, complaining of muscle cramps. He has an EKG monitor on showing peaked T-waves.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Chvostek's sign is positive (facial muscle twitching when tapping the facial nerve).

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Calcium Gluconate, Insulin, and Dextrose
stabilizing.description: Emergency treatment for hyperkalemia has been administered to stabilize the cardiac membrane and shift potassium intracellularly. The peaked T-waves on the EKG have resolved.

improving.trigger: Administer IV Rasburicase and start aggressive IV hydration
improving.description: After treatment with rasburicase and continuous IV fluids, the patient's uric acid levels have normalized, and his renal function and other electrolyte abnormalities are beginning to improve.

orderableItems.result: Potassium: 6.8 mEq/L (high), Phosphate: 9.5 mg/dL (high), Calcium: 7.1 mg/dL (low), Creatinine: 2.5 mg/dL (high).
18 mg/dL (high).
A dose of rasburicase is given to rapidly break down uric acid.
Nephrology consulted for management of AKI and electrolyte disturbances. Recommends continuous hydration and consideration of dialysis if renal function does not improve.
Sinus tachycardia with tall, peaked T-waves and a widened QRS complex, consistent with hyperkalemia.

metadata.title: Pyloric Stenosis
teachingPoints: Pyloric stenosis is a common cause of gastric outlet obstruction in infancy, typically presenting between 3 and 6 weeks of age.
The hallmark symptom is immediate, non-bilious, projectile vomiting after feeding in a hungry infant.
The classic physical exam finding is a palpable, olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium.
Prolonged vomiting leads to a characteristic hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.
Abdominal ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice, showing a thickened and elongated pyloric muscle.
Management involves correction of dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities, followed by definitive surgical treatment with a pyloromyotomy.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Forceful vomiting after every feed.
initialPresentation.summary: A 4-week-old male infant presents with a one-week history of progressive, non-bilious, projectile vomiting and poor weight gain, with exam and imaging findings confirming hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

history.presentIllness: The infant's parents report that for the past week, he has been vomiting after every feed. The vomiting has become increasingly forceful ('projectile') and contains only milk, no green or yellow bile. Despite the vomiting, he seems very hungry and wants to feed again immediately afterward. He has not been gaining weight and has had fewer wet diapers.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: First-born male, born full-term, uncomplicated delivery.

initial.description: The infant is alert but appears fussy and dehydrated, with a sunken fontanelle and dry mucous membranes.

physicalExamFindings.General: Appears thin, with decreased skin turgor and a sunken anterior fontanelle.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: After a test feed, visible peristaltic waves are seen moving from left to right across the upper abdomen. A firm, mobile, 2 cm olive-shaped mass is palpated in the epigastrium.

stabilizing.trigger: IV Fluid Resuscitation with D5 1/2 NS + KCl
stabilizing.description: The infant is receiving IV fluids to correct his dehydration and metabolic alkalosis prior to surgery. His urine output has improved.

improving.description: The infant is now 12 hours post-operative. He has tolerated his first feed without vomiting and appears comfortable. His electrolyte abnormalities have resolved.

orderableItems.result: Sodium: 132, Potassium: 2.9 (low), Chloride: 85 (low), Bicarbonate: 32 (high). Findings of a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.
Pyloric muscle thickness is 5 mm and channel length is 18 mm. Findings are diagnostic for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
Surgery consulted. Recommends admission for IV fluid correction of electrolyte abnormalities, followed by pyloromyotomy once stable.
Successful Ramstedt pyloromyotomy performed. The infant tolerated the procedure well.

metadata.title: Delirium Tremens
teachingPoints: Delirium tremens (DTs) is the most severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal, occurring 48-96 hours after the last drink.

It is a medical emergency characterized by delirium (confusion, disorientation), agitation, hallucinations (often visual or tactile), and profound autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever).
Management is centered on symptom-triggered benzodiazepine administration (e.g., lorazepam, diazepam) using a validated scale like the CIWA-Ar.
Supportive care includes IV fluids, nutritional support, and aggressive repletion of thiamine (to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy), folate, and other electrolytes.
Patients with DTs require admission to a monitored setting, often an ICU, for management of agitation and potential complications.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Agitation and confusion.
initialPresentation.summary: A 54-year-old male with a history of severe alcohol use disorder, admitted for community-acquired pneumonia, develops profound agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability on hospital day 3, consistent with delirium tremens.

history.presentIllness: The patient was admitted 3 days ago for pneumonia and has been receiving IV antibiotics. He has a long history of daily, heavy alcohol use, with his last drink being on the morning of admission. Today, the nursing staff reports he has become severely agitated, confused, and is talking to people who are not there. He is pulling at his IV lines and believes there are insects crawling on his skin.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Drinks a pint of vodka daily.

initial.description: Patient is severely agitated, diaphoretic, and tremulous. He is disoriented and actively hallucinating.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Disoriented to person, place, and time. Gross tremor of the hands. Picking at his skin and clothes. Does not follow commands.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Lorazepam 4 mg
stabilizing.description: After an initial large dose of a benzodiazepine, the patient is slightly less agitated but remains confused, tachycardic, and hypertensive.

improving.description: After several hours of aggressive, symptom-triggered benzodiazepine therapy in the ICU, the patient is now sedated but arousable. His vital signs are normalizing.

orderableItems.result: Initial CIWA score is 35 (severe withdrawal). Symptom-triggered IV lorazepam is initiated.
High-dose IV thiamine is given to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.
Potassium 3.1, Magnesium 1.3. Electrolytes are being aggressively repleted.
Patient transferred to the ICU for close monitoring and high-dose benzodiazepine therapy.
Consult placed to assist with withdrawal management and plan for long-term substance use treatment upon medical stabilization.

metadata.title: Postpartum Hemorrhage
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) secondary to Uterine Atony
teachingPoints: PPH is a leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality, defined as blood loss >1000 mL or bleeding with signs of hypovolemia within 24 hours of delivery.
The most common cause is uterine atony (the 'boggy' uterus). Other causes include trauma (lacerations), retained tissue, and coagulopathy (the '4 Ts').
Management is a stepwise, escalating process: call for help, start fundal massage, administer uterotonic medications (oxytocin, methylergonovine, carboprost, misoprostol), and ensure IV access.
If medical management fails, escalate to mechanical interventions (e.g., Bakri balloon) or surgical procedures.
Activate a massive transfusion protocol early in cases of severe, ongoing hemorrhage.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Heavy vaginal bleeding after delivery.
initialPresentation.summary: A 38-year-old G1P1 female experiences continuous, heavy vaginal bleeding and develops tachycardia and hypotension immediately following a prolonged labor and vaginal delivery, consistent with postpartum hemorrhage from uterine atony.

history.presentIllness: The patient just delivered a 4.2 kg infant via spontaneous vaginal delivery after a prolonged second stage of labor. The placenta was delivered spontaneously and appeared intact. Immediately following placental delivery, she began to bleed heavily, soaking several pads, and a large amount of clot was expressed from the vagina.

initial.description: Patient is lying in the delivery bed, pale and anxious, with a continuous stream of heavy vaginal bleeding.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: The uterine fundus is soft, boggy, and located 3 cm above the umbilicus.

stabilizing.trigger: Fundal Massage and IV Oxytocin Bolus
stabilizing.description: Vigorous fundal massage is being performed, and a wide-open IV oxytocin infusion is started. The uterus firms up transiently but becomes boggy again when massage is stopped. Bleeding continues.

improving.trigger: Administer IM Carboprost and place Bakri Balloon
improving.description: After administration of second-line uterotonics and placement of an intrauterine balloon tamponade device, the bleeding has significantly decreased and the uterus is now firm. The patient's vital signs are stabilizing.

orderableItems.result: Uterus becomes firm with massage but remains boggy without it. Clots are expressed.
High-dose oxytocin infusion started. Provides transient improvement in uterine tone.
Second-line uterotonic administered. Uterine tone improves.
An intrauterine balloon is placed and inflated, providing direct tamponade to the uterine wall. Bleeding is now controlled.
Protocol activated. Patient receives 2 units of pRBCs and 2 units of FFP.

metadata.title: Nephrotic Syndrome
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Minimal Change Disease causing Nephrotic Syndrome
teachingPoints: Nephrotic syndrome is a clinical syndrome defined by the tetrad of heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia (<3.0 g/dL), peripheral edema, and hyperlipidemia.
The profound loss of albumin lowers oncotic pressure, causing massive third-spacing of fluid and anasarca.
Patients are at high risk for thromboembolism (due to loss of anticoagulant proteins) and infection (due to loss of immunoglobulins).
Minimal Change Disease is the most common cause in children but can also occur in adults, and is often responsive to corticosteroids.
Diagnosis in adults often requires a renal biopsy to determine the underlying glomerular pathology.
Management involves treating the underlying cause, managing edema with diuretics, and addressing complications like hyperlipidemia and thrombosis risk.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Massive swelling in his legs and face.
initialPresentation.summary: A 32-year-old male presents with rapid onset of anasarca, with laboratory findings of heavy proteinuria and severe hypoalbuminemia, confirming a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome.

history.presentIllness: Over the past two weeks, the patient has noticed progressive swelling in his legs, which has now extended to his abdomen and face (anasarca). He has gained 25 pounds. His urine has appeared very 'frothy' or 'foamy.' He feels extremely fatigued but denies shortness of breath or chest pain.

initial.description: Patient is sitting in bed with massive, 4+ pitting edema of his lower extremities up to the sacrum, as well as scrotal and periorbital edema.
