physicalExamFindings.Extremities: 4+ pitting edema to the thighs and sacrum.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Furosemide
stabilizing.description: After a large dose of IV diuretics, the patient has had significant urine output, with a 5-pound weight loss. His edema is slightly improved.

improving.description: Following a renal biopsy that confirmed Minimal Change Disease, the patient was started on high-dose oral corticosteroids. After one week, his proteinuria has significantly decreased, and his edema is resolving.

orderableItems.result: Protein: 4+. Oval fat bodies and fatty casts are seen on microscopy.

orderableItems.testName: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP) and Lipid Panel
orderableItems.result: Albumin: 1.5 g/dL (very low). Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL. LDL Cholesterol: 250 mg/dL (high).
12.5 grams/day (severe nephrotic-range proteinuria).
Nephrology confirms diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome. Recommends admission for diuresis, salt restriction, and to perform a renal biopsy.
Light microscopy: normal glomeruli. Electron microscopy: diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes. Diagnosis: Minimal Change Disease.

metadata.title: Splenic Laceration
teachingPoints: The spleen is the most commonly injured organ in blunt abdominal trauma.
Patients may present with left upper quadrant pain, left shoulder pain (Kehr's sign), or signs of hemorrhagic shock.
The FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) exam is a rapid bedside tool to screen for hemoperitoneum.
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast is the gold standard for diagnosing and grading solid organ injuries.
Hemodynamically stable patients without other indications for laparotomy can often be managed non-operatively with close observation in a monitored setting.
Indications for surgical intervention (splenectomy) include hemodynamic instability, contrast extravasation on CT, or failure of non-operative management.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Left-sided abdominal pain after a car accident.
initialPresentation.summary: A 35-year-old male who was a restrained driver in a motor vehicle collision presents with tachycardia and left upper quadrant tenderness, with a positive FAST exam and CT scan confirming a splenic laceration.

history.presentIllness: The patient was the restrained driver in a T-bone collision where his side of the car was impacted. He was able to self-extricate. He complains of severe pain in his left upper abdomen and left shoulder tip. He denies loss of consciousness.

initial.description: Patient is on a backboard with a C-collar in place. He is alert and oriented but in significant pain.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Seatbelt sign across the abdomen. Moderate tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant. No peritoneal signs.

stabilizing.trigger: Perform FAST Exam and give IV Fluid Bolus
stabilizing.description: The FAST exam is positive for free fluid in the splenorenal space. After a fluid bolus, his blood pressure improves, but he remains tachycardic.

improving.trigger: Non-operative management with serial abdominal exams
improving.description: The patient was admitted to the ICU for observation. His vital signs have remained stable, and serial hemoglobin levels are not dropping. His abdominal pain is improving.

orderableItems.result: Positive. A strip of anechoic (black) fluid is seen in the splenorenal recess, concerning for hemoperitoneum.
A Grade III laceration of the spleen is identified with a moderate amount of surrounding hemoperitoneum. No active contrast extravasation is seen.
Trauma team at bedside. Given the patient's hemodynamic stability and lack of active extravasation on CT, they recommend admission for non-operative management.
Initial Hgb is 13.5 g/dL. Repeat Hgb at 4 and 8 hours are stable at 12.8 and 12.5 g/dL, respectively.

metadata.title: C. difficile Colitis
teachingPoints: C. difficile infection (CDI) is a common cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea.
Risk factors include recent antibiotic use (especially clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, and cephalosporins), advanced age, and recent hospitalization.
Symptoms range from mild diarrhea to severe, fulminant colitis with toxic megacolon.
Diagnosis is made by detecting C. difficile toxin or toxin genes in a stool sample (e.g., via PCR).
Initial treatment for a non-severe infection is oral fidaxomicin or oral vancomycin. Metronidazole is no longer first-line.
Severe CDI (WBC >15,000 or Cr >1.5x baseline) is treated with oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin. Fulminant CDI may require the addition of IV metronidazole and surgical consultation.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Multiple episodes of watery diarrhea.
initialPresentation.summary: A 68-year-old male who was recently hospitalized and treated with antibiotics for pneumonia presents with profuse, watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and a high white blood cell count, consistent with severe C. difficile infection.

history.presentIllness: The patient was discharged from the hospital one week ago after being treated with levofloxacin for pneumonia. For the past three days, he has had 10-15 episodes of non-bloody, watery, foul-smelling diarrhea per day. He also has lower abdominal cramping and a low-grade fever. He feels weak and dehydrated.

initial.description: Patient is uncomfortable and appears dehydrated with dry mucous membranes.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, with diffuse lower abdominal tenderness. Bowel sounds are hyperactive.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Fluids and send stool sample
stabilizing.description: After receiving IV fluids, the patient's tachycardia and hypotension have improved. He continues to have frequent diarrhea.

improving.description: After 48 hours of oral vancomycin, the frequency and volume of the patient's diarrhea have significantly decreased. His abdominal cramping has resolved, and his white blood cell count is trending down.

orderableItems.result: Positive for Clostridioides difficile toxin B gene.
WBC: 22,000/mm³ (marked leukocytosis).
BUN: 35, Creatinine: 1.6 (up from a baseline of 1.0), indicating AKI.
Oral vancomycin 125 mg four times daily is started.
ID consulted. Agrees with diagnosis of severe CDI and the treatment plan. Recommends contact precautions.

metadata.title: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome
teachingPoints: NMS is a rare but life-threatening idiosyncratic reaction to dopamine-blocking agents (antipsychotics).
The classic tetrad is altered mental status, rigidity ('lead-pipe' rigidity), fever, and autonomic dysregulation (tachycardia, labile blood pressure).
It is distinguished from serotonin syndrome by the presence of extreme rigidity and a slower onset (days vs. hours).
A markedly elevated creatine kinase (CK) level from muscle breakdown is a key laboratory finding.
Management is a medical emergency: immediately stop the offending antipsychotic, provide aggressive supportive care (cooling, hydration), and transfer to the ICU.
Specific treatments like dantrolene or bromocriptine may be used in severe cases.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Fever and confusion.
initialPresentation.summary: A 34-year-old male with schizophrenia, recently started on a higher dose of haloperidol, presents with high fever, confusion, and diffuse, severe muscle rigidity, consistent with Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome.

history.presentIllness: The patient was brought from his group home due to a 2-day history of increasing confusion and lethargy. Today, he developed a high fever and became extremely stiff, to the point where he is difficult to move. His dose of haloperidol was increased one week ago for worsening psychosis.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Lives in a supervised group home.

initial.description: Patient is catatonic, diaphoretic, and febrile. He has diffuse, severe rigidity in all four limbs.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: Catatonic, does not respond to commands. Diffuse 'lead-pipe' rigidity in both upper and lower extremities. Tremor present.

stabilizing.trigger: Stop Haloperidol and start aggressive IV fluids and cooling
stabilizing.description: The antipsychotic has been discontinued. The patient is receiving IV fluids and is covered in cooling blankets. He remains rigid and hemodynamically unstable.

improving.trigger: Administer IV Dantrolene and transfer to ICU
improving.description: After transfer to the ICU and initiation of dantrolene, the patient's muscle rigidity is beginning to lessen, and his temperature is slowly decreasing. His vital signs are starting to stabilize.

orderableItems.result: 55,000 U/L (Markedly elevated).
WBC: 18,000/mm³ (leukocytosis).
Offending agent discontinued immediately.
Dantrolene, a direct muscle relaxant, is administered to treat the severe rigidity and hyperthermia.
ICU team consulted for management of hyperthermia, autonomic instability, and potential need for intubation.

metadata.title: Adult Epiglottitis
teachingPoints: Adult epiglottitis is a life-threatening infection causing inflammation of the epiglottis and supraglottic structures, which can lead to sudden airway obstruction.
Unlike in children, the presentation can be more variable, but the classic signs are a severe sore throat, dysphagia, drooling, and a 'hot potato' voice.
Patients often assume a 'tripod' position to optimize their airway.
Any attempt to visualize the pharynx with a tongue depressor is contraindicated as it may precipitate complete airway obstruction.
Diagnosis is confirmed by laryngoscopy (showing a swollen, cherry-red epiglottis) or a lateral neck X-ray (showing the 'thumbprint sign').
This is an airway emergency. The patient should be kept calm, and an anesthesiologist and ENT surgeon should be consulted immediately for airway management, often in the operating room.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Rapidly worsening sore throat and difficulty swallowing.
initialPresentation.summary: A 48-year-old male presents with a rapidly progressing severe sore throat, dysphagia, and drooling, with inspiratory stridor, concerning for acute epiglottitis and impending airway compromise.

history.presentIllness: The patient had a mild sore throat yesterday. He awoke this morning with a severe sore throat (10/10), profound pain on swallowing (odynophagia), and has been unable to eat or drink. His voice has become muffled, and he is now drooling because it is too painful to swallow his own saliva. Over the past hour, he has developed noisy breathing.

initial.description: Patient is sitting upright, leaning forward (tripod position), and is drooling. He is anxious and in obvious respiratory distress with audible inspiratory stridor.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Voice is muffled ('hot potato' voice). Pharynx is not visualized to avoid precipitating airway closure.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer humidified oxygen and prepare for difficult airway
stabilizing.description: The patient is receiving blow-by humidified oxygen. Anesthesia and ENT are at the bedside. The patient is being kept as calm as possible while preparations are made for definitive airway management.

improving.trigger: Emergent Intubation in the Operating Room
improving.description: The patient was taken to the OR where he was safely intubated via fiberoptic laryngoscopy. He is now sedated in the ICU receiving IV antibiotics and steroids. His stridor has resolved.

orderableItems.result: A swollen, enlarged epiglottis is seen, consistent with the 'thumbprint sign'.
Both services consulted emergently for airway management. They agree on taking the patient to the OR for a controlled intubation.
Antibiotics and steroids are administered to treat the infection and reduce inflammation.
A massively swollen, cherry-red epiglottis is visualized, confirming the diagnosis.

metadata.title: Ludwig's Angina
teachingPoints: Ludwig's angina is a rapidly progressive cellulitis of the floor of the mouth, typically arising from an infected mandibular molar.
It is a life-threatening condition due to the potential for posterior and superior swelling to cause airway obstruction.
Key signs include fever, severe neck pain and swelling, drooling, dysphagia, and elevation and posterior displacement of the tongue.
A 'woody' or brawny induration of the submandibular space is a characteristic finding.
This is an airway emergency. Management involves securing the airway (often requiring awake fiberoptic intubation or tracheostomy), broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and surgical incision and drainage.
CT scan of the neck with contrast can confirm the diagnosis and delineate the extent of the infection.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Severe mouth pain and neck swelling.
initialPresentation.summary: A 32-year-old male with a recent toothache presents with fever, drooling, and massive submandibular swelling with elevation of the tongue, consistent with Ludwig's angina and threatened airway.

history.presentIllness: The patient had a severe toothache in his lower left jaw for the past week. Over the last 48 hours, he has developed progressive, painful swelling under his chin and in his neck. He has had difficulty swallowing, has been drooling, and his voice has become muffled. He also has a fever and feels very unwell.

initial.description: Patient is sitting upright, leaning forward, and drooling. He is in moderate respiratory distress and is having difficulty speaking.

physicalExamFindings.HEENT: Massive, tender, brawny ('woody') induration of the submandibular space. The floor of the mouth is elevated, and the tongue is displaced posteriorly and superiorly. A decayed left mandibular molar is noted.

stabilizing.trigger: Prepare for emergent airway management
stabilizing.description: Anesthesia and ENT are at the bedside. The patient is being kept calm while preparations are made for an anticipated difficult airway.

improving.trigger: Awake Fiberoptic Intubation and Surgical Drainage
improving.description: The patient was successfully intubated and taken to the OR for extensive incision and drainage of the sublingual and submandibular spaces. He is now sedated in the ICU with his airway secure.

orderableItems.result: Extensive cellulitis and abscess formation in the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces, with significant edema and effacement of the airway. Confirms Ludwig's angina.

orderableItems.testName: ENT and Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery (OMFS) Consult
orderableItems.result: Both services consulted emergently. Agree on diagnosis and the need for immediate airway control followed by surgical drainage.
Broad-spectrum antibiotics covering oral flora are initiated.
The patient's airway was successfully secured via nasal fiberoptic intubation by anesthesia.

metadata.title: Acetaminophen Overdose
teachingPoints: Acetaminophen overdose is a common and potentially fatal ingestion that can lead to acute liver failure.
The Rumack-Matthew nomogram is used to assess the risk of hepatotoxicity and the need for treatment based on a timed serum acetaminophen level (drawn ≥4 hours post-ingestion).
N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote and is most effective when started within 8 hours of ingestion.
Initial symptoms may be mild or absent, so a high index of suspicion is required for any intentional overdose.
Liver function tests (AST/ALT) may not become elevated until 24-72 hours after the ingestion.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Intentional overdose.
initialPresentation.summary: A 22-year-old female is brought to the ED by her roommate after an intentional ingestion of an unknown quantity of acetaminophen approximately 6 hours prior, following a breakup.

history.presentIllness: The patient's roommate found her crying in her room with an empty bottle of extra-strength acetaminophen. The patient admitted to taking 'a lot' of the pills about 6 hours ago in an attempt to harm herself. She currently complains of mild nausea but denies other symptoms. The bottle was a 100-count of 500mg tablets.

initial.description: Patient is awake, alert, and tearful but cooperative. She complains of mild nausea.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer Activated Charcoal and draw labs
stabilizing.description: A dose of activated charcoal has been given. A timed acetaminophen level and baseline liver function tests have been drawn. The patient is awaiting results.

improving.description: Based on the toxic acetaminophen level, an IV NAC infusion has been started. The patient's nausea has resolved, and she is medically stable while the antidote is infusing.

orderableItems.result: 210 mcg/mL. This plots above the treatment line on the Rumack-Matthew nomogram.
AST: 35 U/L, ALT: 40 U/L. Baseline liver function is normal.
A 21-hour IV NAC protocol is started to prevent hepatotoxicity.
Psychiatry consulted for suicide risk assessment. Recommends admission to the medical floor with 1:1 observation and psychiatric evaluation once medically cleared.

metadata.title: Atrial Fibrillation with RVR
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (RVR)
teachingPoints: Atrial fibrillation is a supraventricular tachyarrhythmia characterized by an 'irregularly irregular' rhythm and absent P waves on EKG.
In a stable patient, the primary goal is rate control to <110 bpm, typically with a beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker.
If the patient is hemodynamically unstable (e.g., hypotensive, altered mental status), immediate synchronized cardioversion is indicated.
Assess stroke risk using the CHA2DS2-VASc score to determine the need for long-term anticoagulation.
Always consider and investigate potential underlying triggers for new-onset AFib, such as infection, pulmonary embolism, or hyperthyroidism.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Palpitations and lightheadedness.
initialPresentation.summary: A 67-year-old female with a history of hypertension presents with the sudden onset of palpitations and lightheadedness. Examination and EKG reveal new onset atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.

history.presentIllness: The patient reports a two-hour history of a 'racing heart' that began suddenly. She also feels lightheaded and mildly short of breath. She denies chest pain, syncope, or focal neurological deficits. Symptoms are persistent.

pastMedicalHistory.medications: Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg daily

initial.description: Patient is alert but anxious, complaining of palpitations. She is tachycardic and mildly hypotensive.

physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, irregularly irregular rhythm. No murmurs. Pulses are rapid and thready.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer IV Diltiazem 20 mg Bolus
stabilizing.description: Following the IV calcium channel blocker, the patient's heart rate has started to decrease, but remains >110 bpm. She reports her symptoms are slightly better.

improving.description: With a continuous infusion, the patient's heart rate is now well-controlled at 80-90 bpm. Her palpitations have resolved, and she no longer feels lightheaded.

orderableItems.result: Irregularly irregular rhythm at ~145 bpm, no discernible P waves, narrow QRS complexes. Consistent with Atrial Fibrillation with RVR.
An initial 20 mg IV bolus followed by a continuous infusion successfully controls the heart rate.
Score is 4 (Age 65-74: 1, Female: 1, Hypertension: 1, Vascular Disease implied by HLD: 1). Anticoagulation is indicated.
Consultant agrees with rate control strategy and recommends starting apixaban for anticoagulation. Advised admission for monitoring.
TSH is normal. Troponin is negative.

metadata.title: IgA Vasculitis (HSP)
teachingPoints: IgA Vasculitis (formerly HSP) is the most common systemic vasculitis in children.
It is characterized by a classic tetrad: palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), arthritis/arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal disease.
The rash is typically located on the lower extremities and buttocks.
While usually self-limited, serious complications can include intussusception and nephritis.
Management is primarily supportive with hydration and pain control (NSAIDs).
Urinalysis should be monitored serially to screen for the development of nephritis, which can have long-term consequences.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Rash on legs and sore ankles.
initialPresentation.summary: A 6-year-old male presents with a palpable purpuric rash on his lower extremities, bilateral ankle pain, and abdominal cramping following a recent upper respiratory infection, consistent with IgA Vasculitis.

history.presentIllness: The patient had a cold about 10 days ago. Three days ago, his parents noticed a red, bumpy rash on his shins and the tops of his feet. The rash has since spread to his thighs and buttocks. He has also been complaining of pain in both ankles, making him limp. For the past day, he has had intermittent, crampy belly pain.

initial.description: The child is alert and playful but limping due to ankle pain. He has a prominent rash on his legs.

physicalExamFindings.Skin: Symmetric, palpable purpura and petechiae distributed over the lower extremities and buttocks. Non-blanching.
physicalExamFindings.Musculoskeletal: Swelling and tenderness to palpation of bilateral ankles. Normal range of motion.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Soft, with mild, diffuse tenderness but no guarding or rebound.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer Ibuprofen
stabilizing.description: After a dose of NSAIDs, the patient reports his ankle pain is much better and he is walking more comfortably.

improving.description: The family has been educated on the natural course of the illness, the importance of monitoring for severe abdominal pain or bloody stools, and the need for follow-up urinalysis. They are comfortable with discharge.

orderableItems.result: Yellow, clear. Negative for blood and protein. (This is a crucial baseline test).
Platelet count is 350,000/uL (normal), ruling out thrombocytopenic purpura.
Patient's arthralgias improve significantly.
Consult not required for typical presentation but would be considered for severe or atypical cases. Diagnosis is clinical.

metadata.title: Acute Cholangitis
teachingPoints: Acute cholangitis is an infection of the biliary tree, most commonly caused by an obstructing gallstone in the common bile duct (choledocholithiasis).
Charcot's triad (fever, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice) is classic but not always present.
Reynolds' pentad (Charcot's triad plus hypotension and altered mental status) indicates severe, life-threatening cholangitis with sepsis.
This is a medical and surgical emergency requiring fluid resuscitation, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and urgent biliary decompression.
ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy and stone extraction is the preferred method for biliary drainage.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Fever, abdominal pain, and yellow skin.
initialPresentation.summary: A 52-year-old female with a history of gallstones presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice, progressing to hypotension and confusion, consistent with acute cholangitis and septic shock.

history.presentIllness: The patient has had intermittent RUQ pain for months. Over the past 24 hours, the pain became constant and severe. She developed high fevers, shaking chills, and her family noted her skin and eyes turned yellow. In the last few hours, she has become confused and lethargic.

initial.description: Patient is ill-appearing, febrile, jaundiced, and confused.

physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Moderate to severe tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant with voluntary guarding.

stabilizing.trigger: Initiate Sepsis Protocol: IV Fluids and Broad-Spectrum Antibiotics
stabilizing.description: After aggressive fluid resuscitation and initiation of antibiotics (Piperacillin-Tazobactam), the patient's blood pressure has improved, but she remains febrile and confused.

improving.description: Following successful biliary decompression via ERCP, the patient's clinical status has dramatically improved. She is no longer hypotensive, her fever is resolving, and her mental status is clearing.

orderableItems.result: Total Bilirubin: 6.8 mg/dL (high), Alk Phos: 450 U/L (high), AST: 250 U/L, ALT: 220 U/L. WBC: 19,500/mm³.
Dilated common bile duct (12 mm) with a visible stone (choledocholithiasis). Thickened gallbladder wall.
Both services consulted emergently. Agree on diagnosis of severe cholangitis and plan for urgent ERCP for source control.
ERCP reveals a stone impacted at the ampulla. A sphincterotomy was performed, and the stone was extracted with a balloon sweep. Purulent bile was drained.

metadata.title: Multiple Sclerosis Flare
teachingPoints: MS is a chronic, immune-mediated demyelinating disease of the central nervous system.
Optic neuritis is a common presenting symptom, characterized by painful, monocular vision loss and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
Diagnosis of MS requires demonstration of dissemination of lesions in space and time, typically via MRI.
MRI of the brain and orbits with gadolinium will show enhancement of the affected optic nerve in acute optic neuritis.
Acute MS relapses causing significant functional disability are treated with high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., IV methylprednisolone).
Long-term management involves disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) to reduce relapse frequency and disability progression.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Painful loss of vision in her left eye.
initialPresentation.summary: A 29-year-old female presents with a 3-day history of progressive, painful, monocular vision loss, with exam findings consistent with optic neuritis as a first presentation of Multiple Sclerosis.

history.presentIllness: Three days ago, the patient noticed pain with left eye movement. Since then, the vision in her left eye has become progressively blurry and dim, as if 'looking through a foggy window.' Colors also appear washed out in that eye. She denies any other neurological symptoms.

initial.description: Patient is alert and cooperative, but anxious about her vision loss.

physicalExamFindings.Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity: Right 20/20, Left 20/200. Left eye has decreased color vision (desaturation). A left relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is present. Fundoscopic exam is normal.

stabilizing.trigger: Obtain urgent MRI of Brain and Orbits
stabilizing.description: Imaging has been completed and confirms the suspected diagnosis. The patient is being prepared for admission and treatment.

improving.description: After two days of high-dose IV steroids, the patient reports the pain with eye movement has resolved and her vision is starting to slowly improve.

orderableItems.testName: Check for Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD)
orderableItems.result: Positive on the left. When swinging the flashlight from the right eye to the left, the left pupil paradoxically dilates.

orderableItems.testName: MRI of Brain and Orbits with Gadolinium
orderableItems.result: Enhancement and swelling of the left optic nerve. Additionally, multiple T2 hyperintense lesions are seen in the periventricular white matter, consistent with demyelinating plaques.
A 3-day course of 1 gram IV methylprednisolone is started to hasten visual recovery.

Neurology confirms diagnosis of clinically definite MS based on the clinical presentation and MRI findings. They will manage the acute steroid treatment and arrange outpatient follow-up to discuss long-term disease-modifying therapy.

metadata.title: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
teachingPoints: OCD is characterized by obsessions (recurrent, intrusive, unwanted thoughts causing anxiety) and/or compulsions (repetitive behaviors or mental acts performed to reduce anxiety).
The compulsions are time-consuming (e.g., >1 hour/day) and cause significant distress or functional impairment.
It is important to differentiate OCD from other anxiety disorders or normal worries.
The Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS) is a tool used to rate the severity of OCD symptoms.
First-line treatment is a combination of a high-dose Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI) and a specific type of cognitive-behavioral therapy called Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP).
Patients often have poor insight into the irrationality of their behaviors.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Fear of contamination and excessive handwashing.
initialPresentation.summary: A 35-year-old male presents with debilitating intrusive thoughts about germs and contamination, which he attempts to neutralize with compulsive handwashing rituals that consume several hours of his day.

history.presentIllness: For the past year, the patient has had an overwhelming fear of contamination from germs. He has intrusive thoughts that everything he touches is dirty and will make him sick. To reduce his anxiety, he engages in handwashing rituals that last up to 30 minutes each time, washing his hands over 20 times a day. His hands are raw and cracked. These rituals have made him late for work and caused him to avoid social situations. He recognizes the fear is excessive but feels powerless to stop the behaviors.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Works as a writer, lives alone.

initial.description: Patient is anxious and fidgety during the interview. His hands are visibly red, dry, and cracked.

physicalExamFindings.Skin: Severe xerosis and lichenification with cracking and fissures on the dorsum of both hands.

stabilizing.trigger: Administer Y-BOCS Scale
stabilizing.description: The symptom severity scale is administered, confirming severe OCD. The patient is provided with psychoeducation about the diagnosis.

improving.trigger: Initiate Fluvoxamine and refer for ERP therapy
improving.description: The patient has started a high-dose SSRI and has his first appointment with a therapist specializing in Exposure and Response Prevention. He expresses hope about starting treatment.

orderableItems.result: Score of 28, indicating severe OCD.
SSRI started at a low dose and titrated up towards a target high dose, as is standard for OCD.

orderableItems.testName: Refer for Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) Therapy
orderableItems.result: Referral placed to a cognitive-behavioral therapist specializing in ERP.
Consult placed for management of severe irritant contact dermatitis of the hands.

metadata.title: Placental Abruption
teachingPoints: Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery of the fetus.
It is a life-threatening emergency for both mother and fetus.
The classic presentation is the triad of painful vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness/hypertonicity, and fetal distress.
Risk factors include hypertension, trauma, smoking, and cocaine use.
This is a clinical diagnosis; ultrasound is not sensitive for detecting abruption.
Management depends on gestational age and maternal/fetal stability, but often requires immediate delivery via emergency Cesarean section.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding at 36 weeks gestation.
initialPresentation.summary: A 34-year-old G2P1 female at 36 weeks gestation with chronic hypertension presents with acute, painful vaginal bleeding, a rigid uterus, and signs of fetal distress, consistent with a placental abruption.

history.presentIllness: The patient was at home when she experienced the sudden onset of severe, constant abdominal pain and dark red vaginal bleeding. She feels her abdomen is 'rock hard' and is having frequent, painful contractions. She has also noticed decreased fetal movement.

initial.description: Patient is in severe pain, with visible vaginal bleeding. She is anxious and tachycardic.

physicalExamFindings.General: In acute distress due to pain.
physicalExamFindings.Abdomen: Uterus is rigid, tender to palpation, and has high-frequency, low-amplitude contractions.
physicalExamFindings.Fetal Monitoring: Fetal heart rate is in the 90s with recurrent late decelerations and minimal variability.

stabilizing.trigger: Establish two large-bore IVs and prepare for C-section
stabilizing.description: The patient is receiving IV fluids and oxygen. The operating room has been notified, and the patient is being consented for an emergency Cesarean section.

improving.description: A viable infant was delivered and transferred to the NICU. A large retroplacental clot was evacuated. The patient's bleeding is now controlled, and she is stable in the recovery room.

orderableItems.result: Category III tracing showing bradycardia and recurrent late decelerations, indicating severe fetal distress.
A retroplacental hematoma is visualized. Fetus is in cephalic presentation with a heart rate of 90 bpm.
Patient taken for immediate C-section. A 500g retroplacental clot was found, confirming a >50% abruption.
2 units of pRBCs crossmatched and transfused intraoperatively.
Both teams at bedside, coordinating for an emergency delivery.

metadata.title: Compartment Syndrome
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Acute Compartment Syndrome of the Lower Leg
teachingPoints: Acute compartment syndrome is a limb-threatening surgical emergency caused by increased pressure within a fascial compartment, compromising circulation and function.
It most commonly occurs after a high-energy trauma, such as a tibial fracture.
The most sensitive early sign is pain out of proportion to the injury, especially with passive stretch of the muscles in the affected compartment.
The classic '6 Ps' (Pain, Paresthesia, Pallor, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia, Paralysis) are often late and unreliable findings; pulselessness is a very late sign.
Diagnosis is clinical, but can be confirmed by measuring compartment pressures (a delta pressure <30 mmHg is diagnostic).
Treatment is emergent fasciotomy to release the pressure.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Unrelenting, worsening pain in his lower leg after a fracture.
initialPresentation.summary: A 34-year-old male who sustained a tibial fracture in a skiing accident develops escalating pain that is unresponsive to opioids, with a tense and swollen lower leg, consistent with acute compartment syndrome.

history.presentIllness: The patient was involved in a skiing accident 6 hours ago and sustained a closed fracture of his left tibia. He was splinted and given IV morphine in the ED. Over the past 2 hours, despite additional doses of pain medication, the pain in his leg has become excruciating and unrelenting. He also complains of numbness and tingling in his foot.

initial.description: Patient is in agony, writhing on the gurney despite having received significant doses of opioids. His left lower leg is extremely swollen and tense within the splint.

physicalExamFindings.Left Lower Leg: The leg is removed from the splint. All four compartments are rock-hard and exquisitely tender to palpation. Pain is elicited with passive dorsiflexion and plantarflexion of the toes. Sensation is decreased over the dorsum of the foot. Dorsalis pedis pulse is 2+.

stabilizing.trigger: Measure Compartment Pressures
stabilizing.description: Intracompartmental pressures are measured and found to be critically elevated, confirming the clinical diagnosis.

improving.description: The patient is in the recovery room after surgery. The fasciotomy wounds are open and packed. The compartments are soft, and he reports significant relief of the deep, aching pain.

orderableItems.result: Positive. Patient reports excruciating pain in the calf with passive extension of the great toe (stretching the anterior compartment).
Anterior compartment pressure is 65 mmHg (normal is <10 mmHg). Delta pressure (Diastolic BP - Compartment Pressure) is 20 mmHg, confirming compartment syndrome.
Orthopedics emergently consulted. Confirms clinical diagnosis and takes patient immediately to the operating room.
A dual-incision fasciotomy was performed, releasing all four compartments of the lower leg. Muscles were found to be bulging but viable.

metadata.title: Status Asthmaticus
teachingPoints: Status asthmaticus is a severe, life-threatening asthma exacerbation that is refractory to standard initial bronchodilator treatments.
A 'silent chest' is an ominous sign, indicating such poor air movement that wheezing is no longer audible.
Pulsus paradoxus and tripoding are signs of severe respiratory distress and impending respiratory failure.
Management involves continuous nebulized albuterol, IV corticosteroids, and IV magnesium sulfate. Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (BiPAP) can help reduce the work of breathing.
A normalizing pCO2 or rising pCO2 on a blood gas in a tachypneic patient is a sign of tiring and impending respiratory arrest, and is an indication for intubation.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Severe shortness of breath and wheezing.
initialPresentation.summary: A 24-year-old male with a history of severe persistent asthma presents with extreme respiratory distress, unable to speak, and a 'silent chest' on exam, consistent with status asthmaticus and impending respiratory failure.

history.presentIllness: The patient has had a cold for two days. His asthma flared this morning, and he has used his albuterol inhaler multiple times without relief. Over the past hour, his breathing has become extremely difficult, and he is now too short of breath to speak. His roommate called 911.

pastMedicalHistory.medicalHistory: Severe persistent asthma, with a prior ICU admission requiring intubation.

initial.description: Patient is sitting bolt upright, tripoding, and using all accessory muscles. He is diaphoretic, cyanotic, and unable to speak.

physicalExamFindings.Pulmonary: Tachypneic with minimal air movement on auscultation. No wheezing is audible ('silent chest').

stabilizing.trigger: Initiate continuous Albuterol nebulizer, IV Solu-Medrol, and IV Magnesium
stabilizing.description: After aggressive initial medical management, the patient has started to move some air, and faint wheezing is now audible. He remains in severe distress.

improving.trigger: Initiate BiPAP and give IV Epinephrine
improving.description: With the addition of non-invasive ventilation and IV epinephrine, the patient's work of breathing has significantly improved. Wheezing is now loud and diffuse, and his oxygenation is better. He is avoiding intubation for now.

orderableItems.result: pH 7.25, pCO2 55 mmHg, PaO2 60 mmHg. Respiratory acidosis indicating respiratory muscle fatigue.
High-dose continuous nebulized beta-agonist therapy is started.
A 2g IV bolus of magnesium is given for its bronchodilatory effects.
Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation is started to decrease the work of breathing and prevent intubation.
ICU team at bedside, managing the patient's respiratory failure and considering indications for intubation.

metadata.title: Tuberculous Meningitis
teachingPoints: TB meningitis is the most severe form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis.
It typically has a subacute presentation over weeks with vague symptoms like headache, low-grade fever, and personality changes, progressing to lethargy and coma.
Cranial nerve palsies, especially of CN VI, are a common finding.
Lumbar puncture is key for diagnosis. CSF typically shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis, very high protein, and very low glucose.
An acid-fast bacillus (AFB) smear of the CSF is often negative, but CSF PCR and culture can confirm the diagnosis.
Treatment requires a prolonged, multi-drug anti-tuberculous regimen (e.g., RIPE) and adjunctive corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and mortality.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Worsening headache and confusion for 3 weeks.
initialPresentation.summary: A 42-year-old male immigrant from an endemic country presents with a several-week history of progressive headache, fever, and lethargy, with CSF findings consistent with tuberculous meningitis.

history.presentIllness: The patient presents with a 3-week history of a constant, dull headache that has been progressively worsening. Over the past week, he has developed low-grade fevers, night sweats, and has become increasingly lethargic and confused. His family also notes he has been complaining of double vision.

pastMedicalHistory.socialHistory: Immigrated from the Philippines 5 years ago.

initial.description: Patient is lethargic, oriented only to person. He has a stiff neck.

physicalExamFindings.Neurological: GCS 13. Nuchal rigidity is present. A left CN VI palsy is noted (unable to abduct the left eye).

stabilizing.trigger: Obtain CT Head and perform Lumbar Puncture
stabilizing.description: Imaging shows basilar meningeal enhancement, and the CSF results are highly suggestive of TB meningitis. The patient is being admitted.

improving.description: After several days of anti-tuberculous and steroid therapy, the patient's mental status is improving. He is more alert and his headache is less severe.

orderableItems.result: Opening pressure: 280 mmH2O. WBC: 250 (85% lymphocytes). Protein: 350 mg/dL (very high). Glucose: 30 mg/dL (very low).

orderableItems.testName: CSF AFB Smear and TB PCR
orderableItems.result: AFB smear is negative. TB PCR is positive.
Thick, abnormal enhancement of the basilar meninges. Small tuberculomas are also noted.
A four-drug regimen (Rifampin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol) is started along with adjunctive corticosteroids.
ID confirms diagnosis and will manage the complex, long-term anti-tuberculous regimen and monitor for drug toxicities.

metadata.title: Pheochromocytoma
teachingPoints: Pheochromocytoma is a rare catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla.
The classic triad is paroxysmal headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis, often accompanied by severe hypertension.
Diagnosis is made by biochemical testing showing elevated plasma free metanephrines or 24-hour urinary fractionated metanephrines.
Once biochemically confirmed, imaging (CT or MRI of the abdomen) is used to localize the tumor.
Pre-operative medical management is crucial to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crisis. This involves alpha-blockade first (e.g., phenoxybenzamine), followed by beta-blockade.
Never start a beta-blocker first, as unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation can lead to a catastrophic hypertensive crisis.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Episodes of racing heart, headache, and sweating.
initialPresentation.summary: A 42-year-old female presents with a history of paroxysmal episodes of severe hypertension, headaches, and palpitations, with biochemical testing confirming a pheochromocytoma.

history.presentIllness: For the past six months, the patient has had episodes that occur 2-3 times a week, lasting about 15-20 minutes. During these 'spells,' she experiences a sudden, pounding headache, a feeling of her heart racing, and profuse sweating. She also feels a sense of impending doom. Between episodes, she feels fine. Her primary care doctor noted her blood pressure was extremely high during one of these episodes.

initial.description: Patient is in clinic for an outpatient evaluation. She is well-appearing and asymptomatic between her paroxysmal episodes.

physicalExamFindings.Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

stabilizing.trigger: Initiate Alpha-Blockade (Phenoxybenzamine)
stabilizing.description: After biochemical confirmation of the diagnosis, the patient is started on an alpha-blocker. She is tolerating the medication well with some orthostatic dizziness, and her blood pressure is gradually coming down.

improving.description: The patient has undergone a successful laparoscopic adrenalectomy. Post-operatively, her blood pressure has normalized, and she no longer requires antihypertensive medications.

orderableItems.result: Normetanephrine: 2500 pg/mL (high), Metanephrine: 1500 pg/mL (high). Results are highly suggestive of a pheochromocytoma.
A 4 cm, avidly enhancing, heterogeneous mass is identified in the right adrenal gland.
Patient started on phenoxybenzamine, which is slowly titrated up over 2 weeks to control blood pressure and allow for volume expansion prior to surgery.
Endocrinology manages the pre-operative alpha and beta blockade. Endocrine surgery is consulted and plans for a laparoscopic adrenalectomy.
The right adrenal mass was successfully resected. Pathology confirmed pheochromocytoma.

metadata.title: Lupus Nephritis
metadata.finalDiagnosis: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) Flare with Class IV Lupus Nephritis
teachingPoints: SLE is a chronic, multisystem autoimmune disease with a wide range of clinical manifestations.
Lupus nephritis is a common and serious complication that can lead to end-stage renal disease.
A flare should be suspected in a known lupus patient with new or worsening symptoms like fatigue, arthralgias, rash, and signs of renal involvement (edema, foamy urine).
Key serologic markers for a flare include rising anti-dsDNA antibody titers and falling complement levels (C3, C4).
A new finding of proteinuria with red blood cell casts on urinalysis is highly concerning for active nephritis.
A renal biopsy is essential to classify the type of lupus nephritis and guide the intensity of immunosuppressive therapy.

initialPresentation.chiefComplaint: Worsening joint pain, fatigue, and leg swelling.
initialPresentation.summary: A 28-year-old female with a known history of SLE presents with a constitutional and articular flare, now with new-onset edema and an active urinary sediment, concerning for lupus nephritis.

history.presentIllness: The patient has had SLE for 5 years. For the past month, she has had worsening fatigue and debilitating pain in her hands and knees. Over the last week, she has developed significant swelling in her legs and notes her urine has become foamy. She also has a new rash on her face.

initial.description: Patient is fatigued and has visible swelling of her hands and lower legs.

physicalExamFindings.Skin: Erythematous, malar rash across the cheeks and nose.
physicalExamFindings.Musculoskeletal: Swelling and tenderness of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints bilaterally.

stabilizing.trigger: Obtain labs and urinalysis
stabilizing.description: Labs confirm an active flare with renal involvement. The patient is being admitted for further workup and treatment.

improving.trigger: Initiate high-dose IV corticosteroids and Mycophenolate
improving.description: After a renal biopsy confirmed proliferative nephritis, the patient was started on induction immunosuppressive therapy. Her edema and arthralgias are improving, and her proteinuria is decreasing.

orderableItems.result: Protein 3+, Blood 2+. Microscopy shows 20-30 RBCs/hpf and red blood cell casts.
Anti-dsDNA: 1:640 (high titer). Complement C3: 45 mg/dL (low), C4: 8 mg/dL (low).
Diffuse, global endocapillary and mesangial hypercellularity with wire loop lesions. Diagnosis: Class IV Lupus Nephritis.
Both services are co-managing the patient. They recommend induction therapy with IV methylprednisolone followed by oral mycophenolate mofetil.
Patient receives pulse IV steroids and is started on mycophenolate for long-term treatment.
